1: Of hem that writen ous tofore
2: The bokes duelle, and we therfore
3: Ben tawht of that was write tho:
4: Forthi good is that we also
5: In oure tyme among ous hiere
6: Do wryte of newe som matiere,
8: So that it myhte in such a wyse,
9: Whan we ben dede and elleswhere,
12: Bot for men sein, and soth it is,
13: That who that al of wisdom writ
14: It dulleth ofte a mannes wit
15: To him that schal it aldai rede,
16: For thilke cause, if that ye rede,
17: I wolde go the middel weie
18: And wryte a bok betwen the tweie,
19: Somwhat of lust, somewhat of lore,
20: That of the lasse or of the more
21: Som man mai lyke of that I wryte:
22: And for that fewe men endite
23: In oure englissh, I thenke make
25: The yer sextenthe of kyng Richard.
27: God wot, for now upon this tyde
28: Men se the world on every syde
30: That it welnyh stant al reversed,
31: As forto speke of tyme ago.
32: The cause whi it changeth so
34: The thing so open is at yµe
35: That every man it mai beholde:
37: Whan that the bokes weren levere,
40: For hier in erthe amonges ous,
41: If noman write hou that it stode,
42: The pris of hem that weren goode
43: Scholde, as who seith, a gret partie
44: Be lost: so for to magnifie
45: The worthi princes that tho were,
46: The bokes schewen hiere and there,
48: And tho that deden thanne amis
50: Right as thei stoden in degre,
51: So was the wrytinge of here werk.
52: Thus I, which am a burel clerk,
54: After the world that whilom tok
55: Long tyme in olde daies passed:
56: Bot for men sein it is now lassed,
57: In worse plit than it was tho,
59: The world which neweth every dai,
60: So as I can, so as I mai.
61: Thogh I seknesse have upon honde
62: And longe have had, yit woll I fonde
63: To wryte and do my bisinesse,
64: That in som part, so as I gesse,
65: The wyse man mai ben avised.
66: For this prologe is so assised
67: That it to wisdom al belongeth:
70: The fortune of this worldes chance,
71: The which noman in his persone
72: Mai knowe, bot the god al one.
73: Whan the prologe is so despended,
74: This bok schal afterward ben ended
75: Of love, which doth many a wonder
76: And many a wys man hath put under.
77: And in this wyse I thenke trete
78: Towardes hem that now be grete,
79: Betwen the vertu and the vice
81: Bot for my wittes ben to smale
82: To tellen every man his tale,
85: With whom myn herte is of accord,
86: I sende unto myn oghne lord,
87: Which of Lancastre is Henri named:
88: The hyhe god him hath proclamed
89: Ful of knyhthode and alle grace.
90: So woll I now this werk embrace
91: With hol trust and with hol believe;
92: God grante I mot it wel achieve.
93: If I schal drawe in to my mynde
94: The tyme passed, thanne I fynde
95: The world stod thanne in al his welthe:
96: Tho was the lif of man in helthe,
97: Tho was plente, tho was richesse,
98: Tho was the fortune of prouesse,
99: Tho was knyhthode in pris be name,
101: Write in Cronique is yit withholde;
102: Justice of lawe tho was holde,
104: Was sauf, and al the baronie
110: With charite tho stod in reste:
112: Was schewed thanne in the visage;
113: The word was lich to the conceite
116: Tho was the vertu sett above
117: And vice was put under fote.
118: Now stant the crop under the rote,
121: That love is falle into discord.
122: And that I take to record
123: Of every lond for his partie
124: The comun vois, which mai noght lie;
125: Noght upon on, bot upon alle
126: It is that men now clepe and calle,
127: And sein the regnes ben divided,
128: In stede of love is hate guided,
129: The werre wol no pes purchace,
130: And lawe hath take hire double face,
131: So that justice out of the weie
133: And thus to loke on every halve,
134: Men sen the sor withoute salve,
135: Which al the world hath overtake.
136: Ther is no regne of alle outtake,
137: For every climat hath his diel
138: After the tornynge of the whiel,
141: The hevene wot what is to done,
142: Bot we that duelle under the mone
143: Stonde in this world upon a weer,
145: Of hem that ben the worldes guides
146: With good consail on alle sides
147: Be kept upriht in such a wyse,
149: Of love, which is al the chief
150: To kepe a regne out of meschief.
152: That unto him which the heved is
154: And he scholde ek her trowthe allowe,
155: With al his herte and make hem chiere,
156: For good consail is good to hiere.
157: Althogh a man be wys himselve,
158: Yit is the wisdom more of tuelve;
159: And if thei stoden bothe in on,
160: To hope it were thanne anon
161: That god his grace wolde sende
162: To make of thilke werre an ende,
163: Which every day now groweth newe:
164: And that is gretly forto rewe
166: Which wolde his oghne lif forsake
167: Among the men to yeve pes.
169: That love is fro the world departed,
170: So stant the pes unevene parted
171: With hem that liven now adaies.
172: Bot forto loke at alle assaies,
173: To him that wolde resoun seche
175: It is to wondre of thilke werre,
176: In which non wot who hath the werre;
178: And of desese his part receyveth,
179: And yet ne take men no kepe.
180: Bot thilke lord which al may kepe,
181: To whom no consail may ben hid,
182: Upon the world which is betid,
184: With trewe hertes and with pleine,
186: As he which is king sovereign
190: And take her cause into hise hondes,
191: So that the world may stonde apppesed
192: And his godhede also be plesed.
193: To thenke upon the daies olde,
194: The lif of clerkes to beholde,
195: Men sein how that thei weren tho
196: Ensample and reule of alle tho
197: Whiche of wisdom the vertu soughten.
198: Unto the god ferst thei besoughten
199: As to the substaunce of her Scole,
200: That thei ne scholden noght befole
201: Her wit upon none erthly werkes,
202: Which were ayein thestat of clerkes,
203: And that thei myhten fle the vice
204: Which Simon hath in his office,
205: Wherof he takth the gold in honde.
209: Ne yet a lettre for to sende
215: To fyhte or for to make cheste
216: It thoghte hem thanne noght honeste;
220: To hem was thanne no baillie;
221: The vein honour was noght desired,
222: Which hath the proude herte fyred;
224: And Pride was a vice holde.
226: Yaf thanne and dede gret almesse
227: To povere men that hadden nede:
228: Thei were ek chaste in word and dede,
230: Her lust was al upon the bok,
231: Or forto preche or forto preie,
232: To wisse men the ryhte weie
233: Of suche as stode of trowthe unliered.
234: Lo, thus was Petres barge stiered
235: Of hem that thilke tyme were,
236: And thus cam ferst to mannes Ere
237: The feith of Crist and alle goode
238: Thurgh hem that thanne weren goode
239: And sobre and chaste and large and wyse.
240: Bot now men sein is otherwise,
242: The worldes swerd on honde is take;
244: Whan Crist him self hath bode pes
245: And set it in his testament,
246: How now that holy cherche is went,
248: Hath set to make werre and strif
249: For worldes good, which may noght laste.
250: God wot the cause to the laste
251: Of every right and wrong also;
252: But whil the lawe is reuled so
253: That clerkes to the werre entende,
254: I not how that thei scholde amende
255: The woful world in othre thinges,
256: To make pes betwen the kynges
260: Bot as it thenkth to the manhode,
261: The hevene is ferr, the world is nyh,
262: And veine gloire is ek so slyh,
264: That thei non other thing beholde,
265: Bot only that thei myhten winne.
266: And thus the werres thei beginne,
267: Wherof the holi cherche is taxed,
268: That in the point as it is axed
269: The disme goth to the bataille,
270: As thogh Crist myhte noght availe
271: To don hem riht be other weie.
272: In to the swerd the cherche keie
273: Is torned, and the holy bede
275: Which scholde stonde upon the feith
276: And to this cause an Ere leyth,
278: That scholde be the worldes hele
279: Is now, men sein, the pestilence
283: In eny thing whan thei ben grieved.
285: As it is in the bokes write,
286: He doth ous somdel forto wite
288: Wher god is noght of compaignie:
289: For every werk as it is founded
290: Schal stonde or elles be confounded;
291: Who that only for Cristes sake
293: And noght for pride of thilke astat,
294: To bere a name of a prelat,
295: He schal be resoun do profit
296: In holy cherche upon the plit
297: That he hath set his conscience;
299: Ther ben of suche manie glade,
300: Whan thei to thilke astat ben made,
301: Noght for the merite of the charge,
302: Bot for thei wolde hemself descharge
304: And thus for Pompe and for beyete
305: The Scribe and ek the Pharisee
307: In the chaiere on hyh ben set;
308: Wherof the feith is ofte let,
309: Which is betaken hem to kepe.
310: In Cristes cause alday thei slepe,
311: Bot of the world is noght foryete;
312: For wel is him that now may gete
313: Office in Court to ben honoured.
314: The stronge coffre hath al devoured
318: And ete and drinke and house bothe;
320: For thei no grein of Pite sowe:
323: To studie upon the worldes lore
326: Hath fostred so that it fordoth
327: Of abstinence al that ther is.
329: If Ethna brenne in the clergie,
333: Of that men sen hem so divided.
334: And yit the cause is noght decided;
335: Bot it is seid and evere schal,
336: Betwen tuo Stoles lyth the fal,
337: Whan that men wenen best to sitte:
338: In holy cherche of such a slitte
339: Is for to rewe un to ous alle;
340: God grante it mote wel befalle
341: Towardes him which hath the trowthe.
342: Bot ofte is sen that mochel slowthe,
343: Whan men ben drunken of the cuppe,
344: Doth mochel harm, whan fyr is uppe,
345: Bot if somwho the flamme stanche;
346: And so to speke upon this branche,
347: Which proud Envie hath mad to springe,
352: It were betre dike and delve
353: And stonde upon the ryhte feith,
354: Than knowe al that the bible seith
355: And erre as somme clerkes do.
356: Upon the hond to were a Schoo
357: And sette upon the fot a Glove
361: That Crist in Erthe taghte here,
362: Thei scholden noght in such manere,
363: Among hem that ben holden wise,
368: Bot whan god wole, it schal were oute,
369: For trowthe mot stonde ate laste.
371: Upon the Pope and his astat,
372: Wherof thei falle in gret debat;
373: This clerk seith yee, that other nay,
374: And thus thei dryve forth the day,
375: And ech of hem himself amendeth
376: Of worldes good, bot non entendeth
377: To that which comun profit were.
378: Thei sein that god is myhti there,
379: And schal ordeine what he wile,
380: Ther make thei non other skile
381: Where is the peril of the feith,
382: Bot every clerk his herte leith
383: To kepe his world in special,
386: Is non of hem that underfongeth
388: And thus the riht hath no defence,
389: Bot ther I love, ther I holde.
390: Lo, thus tobroke is Cristes folde,
393: In lacke of hem that ben unware
395: Upon the world in other halve.
396: The scharpe pricke in stede of salve
397: Thei usen now, wherof the hele
398: Thei hurte of that thei scholden hele;
399: And what Schep that is full of wulle
400: Upon his back, thei toose and pulle,
401: Whil ther is eny thing to pile:
402: And thogh ther be non other skile
403: Bot only for thei wolden wynne,
404: Thei leve noght, whan thei begynne,
406: Which is no good schepherdes dede.
407: And upon this also men sein,
408: That fro the leese which is plein
410: Her Orf, for that thei wolden lacche
411: With such duresce, and so bereve
412: That schal upon the thornes leve
413: Of wulle, which the brere hath tore;
414: Wherof the Schep ben al totore
415: Of that the hierdes make hem lese.
416: Lo, how thei feignen chalk for chese,
417: For though thei speke and teche wel,
418: Thei don hemself therof no del:
419: For if the wolf come in the weie,
420: Her gostly Staf is thanne aweie,
421: Wherof thei scholde her flock defende;
422: Bot if the povere Schep offende
423: In eny thing, thogh it be lyte,
424: They ben al redy forto smyte;
425: And thus, how evere that thei tale,
426: The strokes falle upon the smale,
427: And upon othre that ben grete
429: So that under the clerkes lawe
430: Men sen the Merel al mysdrawe,
431: I wol noght seie in general,
432: For ther ben somme in special
433: In whom that alle vertu duelleth,
434: And tho ben, as thapostel telleth,
437: In the manere as Aaron was:
438: Thei ben nothing in thilke cas
439: Of Simon, which the foldes gate
440: Hath lete, and goth in othergate,
441: Bot thei gon in the rihte weie.
442: Ther ben also somme, as men seie,
444: Whos carte goth upon the whieles
448: Of that is noght in the corage.
449: For if men loke in holy cherche,
450: Betwen the word and that thei werche
451: Ther is a full gret difference:
453: That noman schal his soule empeire,
454: For al is bot a chirie feire
455: This worldes good, so as thei telle;
456: Also thei sein ther is an helle,
457: Which unto mannes sinne is due,
459: That wikkid is, and do the goode.
461: It thenkth thei wolden do the same;
462: Bot yet betwen ernest and game
463: Ful ofte it torneth other wise.
466: Of charite, to clothe and fede
467: The povere folk and forto parte
468: The worldes good, bot thei departe
469: Ne thenken noght fro that thei have.
470: Also thei sein, good is to save
473: Bot pleinly forto speke of that,
474: I not how thilke body fat,
475: Which thei with deynte metes kepe
476: And leyn it softe forto slepe,
477: Whan it hath elles al his wille,
479: And natheles I can noght seie,
480: In aunter if that I misseye.
481: Touchende of this, how evere it stonde,
482: I here and wol noght understonde,
483: For therof have I noght to done:
484: Bot he that made ferst the Mone,
485: The hyhe god, of his goodnesse,
486: If ther be cause, he it redresce.
487: Bot what as eny man accuse,
488: This mai reson of trowthe excuse;
489: The vice of hem that ben ungoode
490: Is no reproef unto the goode:
491: For every man hise oghne werkes
492: Schal bere, and thus as of the clerkes
493: The goode men ben to comende,
494: And alle these othre god amende:
495: For thei ben to the worldes yµe
497: To reulen and to taken hiede
498: Betwen the men and the godhiede.
499: Now forto speke of the comune,
500: It is to drede of that fortune
501: Which hath befalle in sondri londes:
502: Bot often for defalte of bondes
503: Al sodeinliche, er it be wist,
504: A Tonne, whanne his lye arist,
506: Which elles scholde noght gon oute;
507: And ek fulofte a litel Skar
508: Upon a Banke, er men be war,
509: Let in the Strem, which with gret peine,
510: If evere man it schal restreigne.
512: He is noght wys who that ne troweth,
513: For it hath proeved ofte er this;
514: And thus the comun clamour is
515: In every lond wher poeple dwelleth,
516: And eche in his compleignte telleth
517: How that the world is al miswent,
519: Yifth every man in sondry wise.
520: Bot what man wolde himself avise,
522: He may wel ate ferste excuse
523: His god, which evere stant in on:
524: In him ther is defalte non,
525: So moste it stonde upon ousselve
526: Nought only upon ten ne twelve,
528: For man is cause of that schal falle.
529: And natheles yet som men wryte
530: And sein that fortune is to wyte,
533: Which causeth al that a man doth:
534: God wot of bothe which is soth.
535: The world as of his propre kynde
536: Was evere untrewe, and as the blynde
538: He blameth that is noght to blame
539: And preiseth that is noght to preise:
540: Thus whan he schal the thinges peise,
541: Ther is deceipte in his balance,
542: And al is that the variance
543: Of ous, that scholde ous betre avise;
544: For after that we falle and rise,
545: The world arist and falth withal,
546: So that the man is overal
547: His oghne cause of wel and wo.
549: Out of the man himself it groweth;
550: And who that other wise troweth,
552: For evere whil thei deden wel,
554: And whan thei deden the contraire,
556: So that it proeveth wel at ende
557: Why that the world is wonderfull
558: And may no while stonde full,
559: Though that it seme wel besein;
560: For every worldes thing is vein,
561: And evere goth the whiel aboute,
562: And evere stant a man in doute,
564: So hath ther noman al his wille.
565: Als fer as evere a man may knowe,
566: Ther lasteth nothing bot a throwe;
567: The world stant evere upon debat,
568: So may be seker non astat,
569: Now hier now ther, now to now fro,
570: Now up now down, this world goth so,
571: And evere hath don and evere schal:
573: A tale writen in the Bible,
577: Stant, why no worldes thing mai laste,
578: Til it be drive to the laste.
579: And fro the ferste regne of alle
580: Into this day, hou so befalle,
581: Of that the regnes be muable
582: The man himself hath be coupable,
587: Fro ferst was every thing present,
589: In such a wise as thou schalt hiere,
591: Hou that this world schal torne and wende,
592: Till it be falle to his ende;
593: Wherof the tale telle I schal,
594: In which it is betokned al.
596: A swevene him tok, the which he kepte
597: Til on the morwe he was arise,
598: For he therof was sore agrise.
599: To Daniel his drem he tolde,
600: And preide him faire that he wolde
603: Me thoghte I syh upon a Stage
604: Wher stod a wonder strange ymage.
605: His hed with al the necke also
606: Thei were of fin gold bothe tuo;
607: His brest, his schuldres and his armes
608: Were al of selver, bot the tharmes,
609: The wombe and al doun to the kne,
610: Of bras thei were upon to se;
611: The legges were al mad of Stiel,
612: So were his feet also somdiel,
613: And somdiel part to hem was take
614: Of Erthe which men Pottes make;
615: The fieble meynd was with the stronge,
616: So myhte it wel noght stonde longe.
617: And tho me thoghte that I sih
618: A gret ston from an hull on hyh
620: Upon the feet of this figure,
621: With which Ston al tobroke was
622: Gold, Selver, Erthe, Stiel and Bras,
623: That al was in to pouldre broght,
624: And so forth torned into noght."
625: This was the swevene which he hadde,
627: And seide him that figure strange
628: Betokneth how the world schal change
629: And waxe lasse worth and lasse,
630: Til it to noght al overpasse.
631: The necke and hed, that weren golde,
632: He seide how that betokne scholde
633: A worthi world, a noble, a riche,
634: To which non after schal be liche.
636: Schal ben a world of lasse worth;
637: And after that the wombe of Bras
638: Tokne of a werse world it was.
639: The Stiel which he syh afterward
641: Bot yet the werste of everydel
642: Is last, whan that of Erthe and Stiel
643: He syh the feet departed so,
645: Whan that the world divided is,
647: For Erthe which is meynd with Stiel
649: Bot if that on that other waste;
650: So mot it nedes faile in haste.
651: The Ston, which fro the hully Stage
652: He syh doun falle on that ymage,
653: And hath it into pouldre broke,
655: And seide how that is goddes myht,
656: Which whan men wene most upryht
658: And that is of this world the laste,
659: And thanne a newe schal beginne,
660: Fro which a man schal nevere twinne;
661: Or al to peine or al to pes
664: The kynges swevene faire and wel
666: Wher that the wiseste of Caldee
667: Ne cowthen wite what it mente;
668: Bot he tolde al the hol entente,
669: As in partie it is befalle.
670: Of gold the ferste regne of alle
671: Was in that kinges time tho,
674: Of al the world in that partie
676: And hield him stille in such a plit,
677: Til that the world began diverse:
678: And that was whan the king of Perse,
679: Which Cirus hyhte, ayein the pes
682: Ryht as thei wolde hemself desire,
685: And slayn was Baltazar the king,
686: Which loste his regne and al his thing.
687: And thus whan thei it hadde wonne,
688: The world of Selver was begonne
689: And that of gold was passed oute:
690: And in this wise it goth aboute
691: In to the Regne of Darius;
692: And thanne it fell to Perse thus,
694: Which wroghte of armes many a wonder,
696: With Grecs, and here astat uplefte,
698: So soffre thei that nedes mote.
699: And tho the world began of Bras,
700: And that of selver ended was;
701: Bot for the time thus it laste,
702: Til it befell that ate laste
703: This king, whan that his day was come,
704: With strengthe of deth was overcome.
705: And natheles yet er he dyde,
706: He schop his Regnes to divide
707: To knyhtes whiche him hadde served,
708: And after that thei have deserved
709: Yaf the conquestes that he wan;
711: Among hem that the Regnes hadde,
712: Thurgh proud Envie which hem ladde,
713: Til it befell ayein hem thus:
715: Which tho was king of Rome lond,
716: With gret bataille and with strong hond
717: Al Grece, Perse and ek Caldee
718: Wan and put under, so that he
720: Bot al the Marche of thoccident
722: As he that was hol lord and Sire,
724: Of al this world the Monarchie,
725: And was the ferste of that honour
726: Which tok the name of Emperour.
730: Tho goth the Regne of Bras aweie,
731: And comen is the world of Stiel,
732: And stod above upon the whiel.
733: As Stiel is hardest in his kynde
734: Above alle othre that men finde
735: Of Metals, such was Rome tho
742: Which to Silvestre in pure almesse
746: And syh the meschief of this cas,
747: Goth in to France forto pleigne,
749: For Cristes sake and Soule hele
750: That he wol take the querele
751: Of holy cherche in his defence.
753: Of god the cause hath undertake,
754: And with his host the weie take
756: Of Rome and al the tirandie
758: And the Cite with strengthe nom;
759: In such a wise and there he wroghte,
760: That holy cherche ayein he broghte
762: The Popes lost, and yaf him more:
763: And thus whan he his god hath served,
764: He tok, as he wel hath deserved,
766: Of Rome and thus was abandoned
768: Into the hond of no Romein;
769: Bot a long time it stod so stille
771: Til that fortune hir whiel so ladde,
773: Noght be the swerd, bot be soffrance
774: Of him that tho was kyng of France,
776: And he resigneth in this cas
778: His Cousin, which a Lombard is.
779: And so hit laste into the yeer
784: So that thei loste the beyete
785: Of worschipe and of worldes pes.
787: Men sein, ful selden is that welthe
788: Can soffre his oghne astat in helthe;
789: And that was on the Lombardz sene,

3516: I wolde, fader, that ye wiste,
3518: Yit hadde I nevere such matiere,
3520: Noght of so mochel that sche sende
3521: Be mowthe and seide, "Griet him wel:"
3522: And thus for that ther is no diel
3525: That I mai nevere, bot I lye,
3527: I wot noght what I scholde have do,
3528: If that I hadde encheson so,
3529: As ye have seid hier manyon;
3530: Bot I fond cause nevere non:
3531: Bot daunger, which welnyh me slowh,
3535: Now axeth furthere of my lif,
3536: For hierof am I noght gultif.
3537: Mi Sone, I am wel paid withal;
3538: For wite it wel in special
3539: That love of his verrai justice
3540: Above alle othre ayein this vice
3542: With al his herte and most it hateth.
3543: And ek in alle maner wise

3546: Which I finde in the bokes write.
3547: Of hem that we Lombars now calle
3548: Albinus was the ferste of alle
3553: That he that time a werre hadde
3554: With Gurmond, which the Geptes ladde,
3555: And was a myhti kyng also:
3556: Bot natheles it fell him so,
3557: Albinus slowh him in the feld,
3558: Ther halp him nowther swerd ne scheld,
3559: That he ne smot his hed of thanne,
3560: Wherof he tok awey the Panne,
3561: Of which he seide he wolde make
3563: To kepe and drawe into memoire

3567: And sesed in his oghne hond,
3570: And was in every mannes sihte
3571: A fair, a freissh, a lusti on.
3572: His herte fell to hire anon,
3573: And such a love on hire he caste,
3574: That he hire weddeth ate laste;
3575: And after that long time in reste
3576: With hire he duelte, and to the beste
3577: Thei love ech other wonder wel.
3578: Bot sche which kepth the blinde whel,
3579: Venus, whan thei be most above,
3580: In al the hoteste of here love,
3581: Hire whiel sche torneth, and thei felle
3582: In the manere as I schal telle.
3583: This king, which stod in al his welthe
3584: Of pes, of worschipe and of helthe,
3585: And felte him on no side grieved,
3586: As he that hath his world achieved,
3587: Tho thoghte he wolde a feste make;

3592: He let ordeine, and sende anon
3595: That every thing be wel arraied:
3600: The lordes in here beste arrai
3602: On jousteth wel, an other bet,

3635: Which stod tofore him on the bord,

3637: This Skulle is fet and wyn therinne,

3640: And sche to his biddinge obeide,
3641: And tok the Skulle, and what hire liste
3642: Sche drank, as sche which nothing wiste

3751: Tak riht good hiede of this matiere.

3755: Of Pride, which I schal eschuie,

3758: Mi Sone, yit in other forme
3759: Ther is a vice of Prides lore,
3760: Which lich an hauk whan he wol sore,
3761: Fleith upon heihte in his delices
3762: After the likynge of his vices,
3763: And wol no mannes resoun knowe,
3764: Till he doun falle and overthrowe.
3765: This vice veine gloire is hote,
3766: Wherof, my Sone, I thee behote
3767: To trete and speke in such a wise,
3768: That thou thee myht the betre avise.
3769: The proude vice of veine gloire
3771: Hise worldes joyes ben so grete,
3772: Him thenkth of hevene no beyete;
3773: This lives Pompe is al his pes:
3775: And therof thenkth he bot a lite,
3776: For al his lust is to delite
3777: In newe thinges, proude and veine,
3778: Als ferforth as he mai atteigne.
3779: I trowe, if that he myhte make
3780: His body newe, he wolde take
3781: A newe forme and leve his olde:
3782: For what thing that he mai beholde,
3783: The which to comun us is strange,
3788: That he beholt he moste newe
3791: Mor jolif than the brid in Maii

3794: So that of him the newe guise
3795: Of lusti folk alle othre take;

3798: And with al this, if that he may
3800: Anon he wext of his corage

3802: Him thenkth ther is no deth comende:

3804: Of love such a maner pride,

3806: Now schrif thee, Sone, in godes pes,
3807: And of thi love tell me plein

3809: Mi fader, as touchinge of al
3810: I may noght wel ne noght ne schal
3812: That I ne have for love be

3817: To make, and also forto peinte
3820: And thus I sang hem forth fulofte
3821: In halle and ek in chambre aboute,

3825: Of al the joie that I made;
3826: For whanne I wolde with hire glade,
3827: And of hire love songes make,
3828: Sche saide it was noght for hir sake,
3829: And liste noght my songes hiere
3830: Ne witen what the wordes were.

3832: Yit couthe I nevere be so gay
3833: Ne so wel make a songe of love,
3835: And have encheson to be glad;

3839: That I nam glad on other side;
3840: For fame, that can nothing hide,
3841: Alday wol bringe unto myn Ere

3843: How that my ladi berth the pris,
3844: How sche is fair, how sche is wis,
3845: How sche is wommanlich of chiere;
3846: Of al this thing whanne I mai hiere,
3847: What wonder is thogh I be fain?

3850: Althogh I may noght with hir dele,
3851: Yit am I wonder glad of that;
3852: For whanne I wot hire good astat,
3853: As for that time I dar wel swere,
3854: Non other sorwe mai me dere,
3855: Thus am I gladed in this wise.
3856: Bot, fader, of youre lores wise,
3857: Of whiche ye be fully tawht,

3859: That I therof am forto wyte.

3861: Mi sone, he seide, and for thi goode
3863: For I thenke upon this matiere

3865: How that ayein this proude vice
3866: The hihe god of his justice
3867: Is wroth and gret vengance doth.
3868: Now herkne a tale that is soth:
3869: Thogh it be noght of loves kinde,
3870: A gret ensample thou schalt finde
3872: Which is so full of vanite.
3873: Ther was a king that mochel myhte,
3875: Of whom that I spak hier tofore.
3876: Yit in the bible his name is bore,
3877: For al the world in Orient
3879: As thanne of kinges to his liche
3880: Was non so myhty ne so riche;
3881: To his Empire and to his lawes,
3882: As who seith, alle in thilke dawes
3884: As thogh he godd of Erthe were.
3885: With strengthe he putte kinges under,
3886: And wroghte of Pride many a wonder;
3887: He was so full of veine gloire,
3888: That he ne hadde no memoire
3889: That ther was eny good bot he,
3891: Til that the hihe king of kinges,
3892: Which seth and knoweth alle thinges,
3895: Thei speke and sounen in his Ere
3896: As thogh thei lowde wyndes were,-
3897: He tok vengance upon this pride.
3898: Bot for he wolde awhile abide
3899: To loke if he him wolde amende,
3900: To him a foretokne he sende,
3901: And that was in his slep be nyhte.
3902: This proude kyng a wonder syhte
3903: Hadde in his swevene, ther he lay:
3904: Him thoghte, upon a merie day
3905: As he behield the world aboute,
3906: A tree fulgrowe he syh theroute,
3907: Which stod the world amiddes evene,
3908: Whos heihte straghte up to the hevene;
3909: The leves weren faire and large,
3910: Of fruit it bar so ripe a charge,
3911: That alle men it myhte fede:
3912: He sih also the bowes spriede
3913: Above al Erthe, in whiche were
3914: The kinde of alle briddes there;
3915: And eke him thoghte he syh also
3916: The kinde of alle bestes go
3918: And fedden hem upon the ground.
3919: As he this wonder stod and syh,
3920: Him thoghte he herde a vois on hih
3922: "Hew doun this tree and lett it falle,
3923: The leves let defoule in haste
3924: And do the fruit destruie and waste,
3925: And let of schreden every braunche,
3926: Bot ate Rote let it staunche.
3927: Whan al his Pride is cast to grounde,
3928: The rote schal be faste bounde,
3929: And schal no mannes herte bere,
3930: Bot every lust he schal forbere
3931: Of man, and lich an Oxe his mete
3932: Of gras he schal pourchace and ete,
3933: Til that the water of the hevene
3934: Have waisshen him be times sevene,
3935: So that he be thurghknowe ariht
3937: And be mad humble to the wille
3938: Of him which al mai save and spille."
3939: This king out of his swefne abreide,

3948: He loveth, for he cowthe wel
3950: To him were alle thinges cowthe,

3952: He was before the kinges face
3953: Asent, and bode that he scholde

3958: He stod long time er he ansuerde,

3966: Sire king, thi swevene mote falle;

4070: It thoghte him thanne good ynowh:
4071: In stede of chambres wel arraied

4074: For othre pilwes hath he non;
4075: The stormes and the Reines falle,

4081: In stede of mete gras and stres,

4087: Whan he behield his Cote of heres,
4088: He wepte and with fulwoful teres
4089: Up to the hevene he caste his chiere
4090: Wepende, and thoghte in this manere;

4092: Thus seide his herte and spak withinne:
4093: "O mihti godd, that al hast wroght
4094: And al myht bringe ayein to noght,
4095: Now knowe I wel, bot al of thee,
4097: In thin aspect ben alle liche,
4098: The povere man and ek the riche,

4100: And thou above alle othre miht.
4101: O mihti lord, toward my vice
4103: And I woll make a covenant,
4104: That of my lif the remenant
4105: I schal it be thi grace amende,
4106: And in thi lawe so despende

4111: And thogh him lacke vois and speche,
4112: He gan up with his feet areche,
4113: And wailende in his bestly stevene

4115: He kneleth in his wise and braieth,
4117: His god, which made him nothing strange,

4119: Anon as he was humble and tame,
4120: He fond toward his god the same,
4121: And in a twinklinge of a lok
4122: His mannes forme ayein he tok,
4123: And was reformed to the regne
4124: In which that he was wont to regne;
4125: So that the Pride of veine gloire
4127: He let it passe. And thus is schewed
4128: What is to ben of Pride unthewed
4130: To whom noman mai be felawe.
4131: Forthi, my Sone, tak good hiede
4133: That thou ne be noght lich a beste.
4134: Bot if thi lif schal ben honeste,
4135: Thou most humblesce take on honde,
4136: For thanne myht thou siker stonde:
4138: A proud man can no love assise;
4139: For thogh a womman wolde him plese,
4140: His Pride can noght ben at ese.
4141: Ther mai noman to mochel blame
4142: A vice which is forto blame;
4144: That mihte falle in blame of Pride,
4145: Which is the werste vice of alle:
4146: Wherof, so as it was befalle,
4147: The tale I thenke of a Cronique
4148: To telle, if that it mai thee like,
4149: So that thou myht humblesce suie
4150: And ek the vice of Pride eschuie,
4151: Wherof the gloire is fals and vein;
4152: Which god himself hath in desdeign,
4153: That thogh it mounte for a throwe,
4154: It schal doun falle and overthrowe.
4155: A king whilom was yong and wys,
4156: The which sette of his wit gret pris.

4161: Wherof he wolde in sondri wise

8313: And seide him that he scholde go
8314: And telle unto his dowhter so
8315: In the manere as he him bad,
8316: How sche that scharpe swerdes blad
8318: So as sche wot wherto it schal.
8319: Forth in message goth this kniht
8321: This scharpe swerd to hire he tok:
8322: Wherof that al hire bodi qwok,
8323: For wel sche wiste what it mente,
8324: And that it was to thilke entente
8326: And to the kniht sche seide: "Yee,
8327: Now that I wot my fadres wille,
8328: That I schal in this wise spille,
8330: And as he wole it schal be do.
8331: Bot now this thing mai be non other,
8332: I wole a lettre unto mi brother,
8333: So as my fieble hand may wryte,
8334: With al my wofull herte endite."
8335: Sche tok a Penne on honde tho,
8336: Fro point to point and al the wo,
8337: Als ferforth as hireself it wot,
8338: Unto hire dedly frend sche wrot,
8339: And tolde how that hire fader grace
8341: And overthat, as thou schalt hiere,
8342: Sche wrot and seide in this manere:
8343: "O thou my sorwe and my gladnesse,
8344: O thou myn hele and my siknesse,
8345: O my wanhope and al my trust,
8346: O my desese and al my lust,
8347: O thou my wele, o thou my wo,
8348: O thou my frend, o thou my fo,
8349: O thou my love, o thou myn hate,
8350: For thee mot I be ded algate.
8351: Thilke ende may I noght asterte,
8352: And yit with al myn hole herte,
8353: Whil that me lasteth eny breth,
8354: I wol the love into my deth.
8355: Bot of o thing I schal thee preie,
8356: If that my litel Sone deie,
8357: Let him be beried in my grave
8358: Beside me, so schalt thou have
8360: For thus it stant of my grevance;
8361: Now at this time, as thou schalt wite,
8362: With teres and with enke write
8363: This lettre I have in cares colde:
8364: In my riht hond my Penne I holde,
8365: And in my left the swerd I kepe,
8366: And in my barm ther lith to wepe
8367: Thi child and myn, which sobbeth faste.
8368: Now am I come unto my laste:
8369: Fare wel, for I schal sone deie,
8370: And thenk how I thi love abeie."
8371: The pomel of the swerd to grounde
8372: Sche sette, and with the point a wounde
8373: Thurghout hire herte anon sche made,
8374: And forth with that al pale and fade
8375: Sche fell doun ded fro ther sche stod.
8376: The child lay bathende in hire blod
8377: Out rolled fro the moder barm,
8378: And for the blod was hot and warm,
8380: Ther was no bote forto winne,
8381: For he, which can no pite knowe,
8382: The king cam in the same throwe,
8383: And sih how that his dowhter dieth
8384: And how this Babe al blody crieth;
8385: Bot al that mihte him noght suffise,
8386: That he ne bad to do juise
8387: Upon the child, and bere him oute,
8388: And seche in the Forest aboute
8389: Som wilde place, what it were,
8390: To caste him out of honde there,
8391: So that som best him mai devoure,
8392: Where as noman him schal socoure.
8393: Al that he bad was don in dede:
8394: Ha, who herde evere singe or rede
8395: Of such a thing as that was do?
8396: Bot he which ladde his wraththe so
8397: Hath knowe of love bot a lite;
8398: Bot for al that he was to wyte,
8400: To do so gret a felonie.
8401: Forthi, my Sone, how so it stonde,
8402: Be this cas thou miht understonde
8403: That if thou evere in cause of love
8404: Schalt deme, and thou be so above
8405: That thou miht lede it at thi wille,
8406: Let nevere thurgh thi Wraththe spille
8408: For it sit every man to have
8409: Reward to love and to his miht,
8410: Ayein whos strengthe mai no wiht:
8411: And siththe an herte is so constreigned,
8413: To him that mai no bet aweie,
8414: Whan he mot to nature obeie.
8415: For it is seid thus overal,
8416: That nedes mot that nede schal
8417: Of that a lif doth after kinde,
8418: Wherof he mai no bote finde.
8419: What nature hath set in hir lawe
8420: Ther mai no mannes miht withdrawe,
8422: Fulofte time it hath be sein,
8426: Tolde an ensample and seide so,
8428: As he walkende goth per cas,
8429: Upon an hih Montaine he sih
8430: Tuo Serpentz in his weie nyh,
8431: And thei, so as nature hem tawhte,
8432: Assembled were, and he tho cawhte
8433: A yerde which he bar on honde,
8434: And thoghte that he wolde fonde
8435: To letten hem, and smot hem bothe:
8437: And for he hath destourbed kinde
8438: And was so to nature unkinde,
8440: That he which erst a man was formed
8442: That was to him an angri jape;
8443: Bot for that he with Angre wroghte,
8445: Lo thus, my Sone, Ovide hath write,
8446: Wherof thou miht be reson wite,
8447: More is a man than such a beste:
8448: So mihte it nevere ben honeste
8449: A man to wraththen him to sore
8450: Of that an other doth the lore
8451: Of kinde, in which is no malice,
8452: Bot only that it is a vice:
8453: And thogh a man be resonable,
8454: Yit after kinde he is menable
8455: To love, wher he wole or non.
8458: For love hath evere his lust to pleie,
8459: As he which wolde no lif grieve.
8460: Mi fader, that I mai wel lieve;
8461: Al that ye tellen it is skile:
8462: Let every man love as he wile,
8463: Be so it be noght my ladi,
8464: For I schal noght be wroth therby.
8465: Bot that I wraththe and fare amis,
8466: Al one upon miself it is,
8467: That I with bothe love and kinde
8468: Am so bestad, that I can finde
8469: No weie how I it mai asterte:
8470: Which stant upon myn oghne herte
8471: And toucheth to non other lif,
8472: Save only to that swete wif
8473: For whom, bot if it be amended,
8475: That I miself schal noght forbere
8476: The Wraththe which that I now bere,
8477: For therof is non other leche.
8478: Now axeth forth, I yow beseche,
8479: Of Wraththe if ther oght elles is,
8481: Of Wraththe the secounde is Cheste,
8482: Which hath the wyndes of tempeste
8483: To kepe, and many a sodein blast
8485: Thei that desiren pes and reste.
8487: Which many a lusti love hath twinned;
8488: For he berth evere his mowth unpinned,
8489: So that his lippes ben unloke
8490: And his corage is al tobroke,
8491: That every thing which he can telle,
8492: It springeth up as doth a welle,
8493: Which mai non of his stremes hyde,
8494: Bot renneth out on every syde.
8495: So buillen up the foule sawes
8496: That Cheste wot of his felawes:
8497: For as a Sive kepeth Ale,
8498: Riht so can Cheste kepe a tale;
8499: Al that he wot he wol desclose,
8500: And speke er eny man oppose.
8502: Wher men mai gon out overal
8505: He spekth al that he wot withinne:
8506: Wherof men lese mor than winne,
8507: For ofte time of his chidinge
8508: He bringth to house such tidinge,
8510: He is the levein of the bred,
8511: Which soureth al the past aboute:
8512: Men oghte wel such on to doute,
8513: For evere his bowe is redi bent,
8514: And whom he hit I telle him schent,
8515: If he mai perce him with his tunge.
8516: And ek so lowde his belle is runge,
8517: That of the noise and of the soun
8518: Men feeren hem in al the toun
8519: Welmore than thei don of thonder.
8520: For that is cause of more wonder;
8521: For with the wyndes whiche he bloweth
8524: That I have herd the poeple crie,
8525: And echon seide in his degre,
8527: For men sein that the harde bon,
8529: A tunge brekth it al to pieces.
8530: He hath so manye sondri spieces
8531: Of vice, that I mai noght wel
8533: Bot whan that he to Cheste falleth,
8534: Ful many a wonder thing befalleth,
8535: For he ne can nothing forbere.
8536: Now tell me, Sone, thin ansuere,
8537: If it hath evere so betidd,
8538: That thou at eny time hast chidd
8540: Such Cheste yit unto this day
8541: Ne made I nevere, god forbede:
8542: For er I sunge such a crede,
8543: I hadde levere to be lewed;
8544: For thanne were I al beschrewed
8545: And worthi to be put abak
8546: With al the sorwe upon my bak
8548: Bot I spak nevere yit be mowthe
8550: And that I durste riht wel vouche
8552: For I wot, of hir gentilesse
8553: That sche me wolde wel excuse,
8554: That I no suche thinges use.
8555: And if it scholde so betide
8557: It myhte noght be to my love:
8558: For so yit was I nevere above,
8559: For al this wyde world to winne
8560: That I dorste eny word beginne,
8561: Be which sche mihte have ben amoeved
8562: And I of Cheste also reproeved.
8563: Bot rathere, if it mihte hir like,
8564: The beste wordes wolde I pike
8565: Whiche I cowthe in myn herte chese,
8566: And serve hem forth in stede of chese,
8567: For that is helplich to defie;
8568: And so wolde I my wordes plie,
8569: That mihten Wraththe and Cheste avale
8570: With tellinge of my softe tale.
8571: Thus dar I make a foreward,
8573: Yit spak I word in such a wise,
8575: This seie I noght, that I fulofte
8576: Ne have, whanne I spak most softe,
8577: Per cas seid more thanne ynowh;
8578: Bot so wel halt noman the plowh
8580: Ne so wel can noman affile
8581: His tunge, that som time in rape
8582: Him mai som liht word overscape,
8583: And yit ne meneth he no Cheste.
8584: Bot that I have ayein hir heste
8586: And how my will is, that ye knowe:
8587: For whan my time comth aboute,
8588: That I dar speke and seie al oute
8589: Mi longe love, of which sche wot
8590: That evere in on aliche hot
8591: Me grieveth, thanne al my desese
8592: I telle, and though it hir desplese,
8593: I speke it forth and noght ne leve:
8594: And thogh it be beside hire leve,
8596: That I do noght ayein the pes;
8597: For thogh I telle hire al my thoght,
8598: Sche wot wel that I chyde noght.
8599: Men mai the hihe god beseche,
8600: And he wol hiere a mannes speche
8601: And be noght wroth of that he seith;
8602: So yifth it me the more feith
8603: And makth me hardi, soth to seie,
8604: That I dar wel the betre preie
8605: Mi ladi, which a womman is.
8606: For thogh I telle hire that or this
8607: Of love, which me grieveth sore,
8608: Hire oghte noght be wroth the more,
8609: For I withoute noise or cri
8612: Thus dar I seie unto this day
8613: Of Cheste in ernest or in game
8614: Mi ladi schal me nothing blame.
8615: Bot ofte time it hath betidd
8616: That with miselven I have chidd,
8618: And that hath ben at every tide,
8619: Whanne I cam to miself al one;
8620: For thanne I made a prive mone,
8621: And every tale by and by,
8622: Which as I spak to my ladi,
8623: I thenke and peise in my balance
8625: And thanne, if that I finde a lak
8626: Of eny word that I mispak,
8627: Which was to moche in eny wise,
8629: And make a chidinge in myn herte,
8630: That eny word me scholde asterte
8631: Which as I scholde have holden inne.
8632: And so forth after I beginne
8633: And loke if ther was elles oght
8634: To speke, and I ne spak it noght:
8635: And thanne, if I mai seche and finde
8636: That eny word be left behinde,
8637: Which as I scholde more have spoke,
8638: I wolde upon miself be wroke,
8640: That al my wit is overgo.
8641: For noman mai his time lore
8642: Recovere, and thus I am therfore
8643: So overwroth in al my thoght,
8644: That I myself chide al to noght:
8645: Thus for to moche or for to lite
8646: Fulofte I am miself to wyte.
8647: Bot al that mai me noght availe,
8648: With cheste thogh I me travaile:
8649: Bot Oule on Stock and Stock on Oule;
8650: The more that a man defoule,
8651: Men witen wel which hath the werse;
8652: And so to me nys worth a kerse,
8653: Bot torneth on myn oghne hed,
8654: Thogh I, til that I were ded,
8655: Wolde evere chyde in such a wise
8656: Of love as I to you devise.
8657: Bot, fader, now ye have al herd
8658: In this manere how I have ferd
8661: Mi Sone, if that thou wistest al,
8663: To love and to his welwillinge,
8666: For who that most can speke faire
8668: Fair speche hath ofte brought above
8669: Ful many a man, as it is knowe,
8670: Which elles scholde have be riht lowe
8671: And failed mochel of his wille.
8672: Forthi hold thou thi tunge stille
8673: And let thi witt thi wille areste,
8674: So that thou falle noght in Cheste,
8675: Which is the source of gret destance:
8678: Which is the leche of alle offence,
8679: As tellen ous these olde wise:
8680: For whan noght elles mai suffise
8681: Be strengthe ne be mannes wit,
8684: Bot he mai nevere longe laste,
8685: Which wol noght bowe er that he breke.
8686: Tak hiede, Sone, of that I speke.
8687: Mi fader, of your goodli speche
8688: And of the witt which ye me teche
8689: I thonke you with al myn herte:
8690: For that world schal me nevere asterte,
8691: That I ne schal your wordes holde,
8692: Of Pacience as ye me tolde,
8693: Als ferforth as myn herte thenketh;
8694: And of my wraththe it me forthenketh.
8695: Bot, fader, if ye forth withal
8697: Me wolden telle of som Cronique,
8698: It scholde wel myn herte like
8700: So that I mihte in mi matiere
8701: The more unto my love obeie
8703: Mi Sone, a man to beie him pes
8706: And for thou schalt the sothe wite,
8707: Of this ensample what I mene,
8708: Althogh it be now litel sene
8711: So sett, that he himself assaie
8712: In thing which mihte him most mispaie
8714: He weddeth, which in sorwe and strif
8716: Bot he spak evere softe and faire,
8717: Til it befell, as it is told,
8718: In wynter, whan the dai is cold,
8719: This wif was fro the welle come,
8720: Wher that a pot with water nome
8721: Sche hath, and broghte it into house,
8722: And sih how that hire seli spouse
8723: Was sett and loked on a bok
8724: Nyh to the fyr, as he which tok
8725: His ese for a man of age.
8726: And sche began the wode rage,
8727: And axeth him what devel he thoghte,
8728: And bar on hond that him ne roghte
8729: What labour that sche toke on honde,
8730: And seith that such an Housebonde
8731: Was to a wif noght worth a Stre.
8732: He seide nowther nay ne ye,
8733: Bot hield him stille and let hire chyde;
8734: And sche, which mai hirself noght hyde,
8736: And that sche broghte in fro the welle,
8738: And bad him speke, and he al softe
8739: Sat stille and noght a word ansuerde;
8740: And sche was wroth that he so ferde,
8741: And axeth him if he be ded;
8742: And al the water on his hed
8743: Sche pourede oute and bad awake.
8744: Bot he, which wolde noght forsake
8746: And seide how that he fond no lak
8747: In nothing which sche hadde do:
8748: For it was wynter time tho,
8749: And wynter, as be weie of kinde
8750: Which stormy is, as men it finde,
8751: Ferst makth the wyndes forto blowe,
8752: And after that withinne a throwe
8755: Which is with reson wel besein,
8756: Hath mad me bothe wynd and rein
8757: After the Sesoun of the yer."
8758: And thanne he sette him nerr the fer,
8759: And as he mihte hise clothes dreide,
8760: That he nomore o word ne seide;
8761: Wherof he gat him somdel reste,
8762: For that him thoghte was the beste.
8763: I not if thilke ensample yit
8765: To soffre as Socrates tho dede:
8766: And if it falle in eny stede
8767: A man to lese so his galle,
8768: Him oghte among the wommen alle
8771: To yive ensample to the goode
8772: Of pacience how that it stode,
8773: That othre men it mihte knowe.
8774: And, Sone, if thou at eny throwe
8777: It schal per cas the lasse grieve.
8778: Mi fader, so as I believe,
8779: Of that schal be no maner nede,
8780: For I wol take so good hiede,
8781: That er I falle in such assai,
8782: I thenke eschuie it, if I mai.
8783: Bot if ther be oght elles more
8785: I preie you, so as I dar,
8786: Now telleth, that I mai be war,
8787: Som other tale in this matiere.
8788: Sone, it is evere good to lere,
8789: Wherof thou miht thi word restreigne,
8790: Er that thou falle in eny peine.
8791: For who that can no conseil hyde,
8792: He mai noght faile of wo beside,
8793: Which schal befalle er he it wite,
8794: As I finde in the bokes write.
8795: Yit cam ther nevere good of strif,
8796: To seche in all a mannes lif:
8797: Thogh it beginne on pure game,
8799: And doth grevance upon som side.
8801: After the lawe which was tho
8805: In manere as it were a borde,
8808: And that was upon this degree,
8809: Which of the tuo more amorous is,
8810: Or man or wif. And upon this
8811: Thei mihten noght acorde in on,
8814: And bede him demen in the cas;
8818: Was wroth and wolde noght forbere,
8820: The liht fro bothe hise yhen tuo.
8821: Whan Jupiter this harm hath sein,
8823: He yaf, and such a grace him doth,
8824: That for he wiste he seide soth,
8825: A Sothseiere he was for evere:
8826: Bot yit that other were levere,
8827: Have had the lokinge of his yhe,
8828: Than of his word the prophecie;
8829: Bot how so that the sothe wente,
8830: Strif was the cause of that he hente
8832: Mi Sone, be thou war ther by,
8833: And hold thi tunge stille clos:
8834: For who that hath his word desclos
8835: Er that he wite what he mene,
8836: He is fulofte nyh his tene
8837: And lest ful many time grace,
8838: Wher that he wolde his thonk pourchace.
8839: And over this, my Sone diere,
8840: Of othre men, if thou miht hiere
8841: In privete what thei have wroght,
8842: Hold conseil and descoevere it noght,
8843: For Cheste can no conseil hele,
8844: Or be it wo or be it wele:
8845: And tak a tale into thi mynde,
8846: The which of olde ensample I finde.
8847: Phebus, which makth the daies lihte,
8848: A love he hadde, which tho hihte
8850: He pleseth: bot what schal befalle
8851: Of love ther is noman knoweth,
8852: Bot as fortune hire happes throweth.
8853: So it befell upon a chaunce,
8854: A yong kniht tok hire aqueintance
8855: And hadde of hire al that he wolde:
8856: Bot a fals bridd, which sche hath holde
8857: And kept in chambre of pure yowthe,
8858: Discoevereth all that evere he cowthe.
8859: This briddes name was as tho
8860: Corvus, the which was thanne also
8862: And he that schrewe al that he can
8863: Of his ladi to Phebus seide;
8864: And he for wraththe his swerd outbreide,
8865: With which Cornide anon he slowh.
8866: Bot after him was wo ynowh,
8867: And tok a full gret repentance,
8869: Of hem whiche usen wicke speche,
8870: Upon this bridd he tok this wreche,
8871: That ther he was snow whyt tofore,
8873: He was transformed, as it scheweth,
8874: And many a man yit him beschreweth,
8875: And clepen him into this day
8876: A Raven, be whom yit men mai
8879: Be war therfore and sei the beste,
8880: If thou wolt be thiself in reste,
8881: Mi goode Sone, as I the rede.
8882: For in an other place I rede
8883: Of thilke Nimphe which Laar hihte:
8884: For sche the privete be nyhte,
8886: Hath told, god made hire overtorne:
8887: Hire tunge he kutte, and into helle
8888: For evere he sende hir forto duelle,
8889: As sche that was noght worthi hiere
8890: To ben of love a Chamberere,
8891: For sche no conseil cowthe hele.
8892: And suche adaies be now fele
8893: In loves Court, as it is seid,
8894: That lete here tunges gon unteid.
8895: Mi Sone, be thou non of tho,
8896: To jangle and telle tales so,
8897: And namely that thou ne chyde,
8898: For Cheste can no conseil hide,
8901: That ye me teche, and I wol holde
8902: The reule to which I am holde,
8903: To fle the Cheste, as ye me bidde,
8904: For wel is him that nevere chidde.
8905: Now tell me forth if ther be more
8907: Of Wraththe yit ther is an other,
8908: Which is to Cheste his oghne brother,
8909: And is be name cleped Hate,
8910: That soffreth noght withinne his gate
8911: That ther come owther love or pes,
8912: For he wol make no reles
8913: Of no debat which is befalle.
8914: Now spek, if thou art on of alle,
8915: That with this vice hast ben withholde.
8916: As yit for oght that ye me tolde,
8917: Mi fader, I not what it is.
8918: In good feith, Sone, I trowe yis.
8919: Mi fader, nay, bot ye me lere.
8920: Now lest, my Sone, and thou schalt here.
8921: Hate is a wraththe noght schewende,
8923: And duelleth in the herte loken,
8924: Til he se time to be wroken;
8925: And thanne he scheweth his tempeste
8926: Mor sodein than the wilde beste,
8927: Which wot nothing what merci is.
8928: Mi Sone, art thou knowende of this?
8929: My goode fader, as I wene,
8930: Now wot I somdel what ye mene;
8931: Bot I dar saufly make an oth,
8932: Mi ladi was me nevere loth.
8934: That I of hate am gulteles;
8935: For whanne I to my ladi plie
8936: Fro dai to dai and merci crie,
8937: And sche no merci on me leith
8938: Bot schorte wordes to me seith,
8939: Thogh I my ladi love algate,
8940: Tho wordes moste I nedes hate;
8941: And wolde thei were al despent,
8942: Or so ferr oute of londe went
8943: That I nevere after scholde hem hiere;
8944: And yit love I my ladi diere.
8945: Thus is ther Hate, as ye mai se,
8946: Betwen mi ladi word and me;
8947: The word I hate and hire I love,
8948: What so me schal betide of love.
8949: Bot forthere mor I wol me schryve,
8950: That I have hated al my lyve
8951: These janglers, whiche of here Envie
8954: Fuloften thei have mad me schent
8956: Whan thei no cause wisten bime,
8957: Bot onliche of here oghne thoght:
8958: And thus fuloften have I boght
8959: The lie, and drank noght of the wyn.
8960: I wolde here happ were such as myn:
8961: For how so that I be now schrive,
8962: To hem ne mai I noght foryive,
8963: Til that I se hem at debat
8964: With love, and thanne myn astat
8965: Thei mihten be here oghne deme,
8966: And loke how wel it scholde hem qweme
8967: To hindre a man that loveth sore.
8968: And thus I hate hem everemore,
8969: Til love on hem wol don his wreche:
8970: For that schal I alway beseche
8972: That he so mochel wolde do,
8973: So as he is of love a godd,
8974: To smyte hem with the same rodd
8975: With which I am of love smite;
8976: So that thei mihten knowe and wite
8977: How hindringe is a wofull peine
8978: To him that love wolde atteigne.
8979: Thus evere on hem I wayte and hope,
8980: Til I mai sen hem lepe a lope,
8981: And halten on the same Sor
8982: Which I do now: for overmor
8983: I wolde thanne do my myht
8984: So forto stonden in here lyht,
8985: That thei ne scholden finde a weie
8986: To that thei wolde, bot aweie
8987: I wolde hem putte out of the stede
8988: Fro love, riht as thei me dede
8989: With that thei speke of me be mowthe.
8990: So wolde I do, if that I cowthe,
8991: Of hem, and this, so god me save,
8992: Is al the hate that I have,
8994: I wolde alle othre ferde wel.
8995: Thus have I, fader, said mi wille;
8996: Say ye now forth, for I am stille.
8997: Mi Sone, of that thou hast me said
8998: I holde me noght fulli paid:
8999: That thou wolt haten eny man,
9000: To that acorden I ne can,
9001: Thogh he have hindred thee tofore.
9002: Bot this I telle thee therfore,
9005: Of tho janglers, as thou me toldest,
9006: Bot furthermor, of that thou woldest
9007: Hem hindre in eny other wise,
9008: Such Hate is evere to despise.
9009: Forthi, mi Sone, I wol thee rede,
9010: That thou drawe in be frendlihede
9011: That thou ne miht noght do be hate;
9012: So miht thou gete love algate
9013: And sette thee, my Sone, in reste,
9014: For thou schalt finde it for the beste.
9015: And over this, so as I dar,
9016: I rede that thou be riht war
9019: For Hate is evere upon await,
9020: And as the fisshere on his bait
9021: Sleth, whan he seth the fisshes faste,
9022: So, whan he seth time ate laste,
9023: That he mai worche an other wo,
9030: The prive wraththe can him clothe,
9031: That he schal seme of gret believe.
9032: Bot war thee wel that thou ne lieve
9033: Al that thou sest tofore thin yhe,
9034: So as the Gregois whilom syhe:
9035: The bok of Troie who so rede,
9036: Ther mai he finde ensample in dede.
9038: Whan Troie was al bete doun
9039: And slain was Priamus the king,
9040: The Gregois, whiche of al this thing
9042: Ther mai noman his happ withsein;
9043: It hath be sen and felt fulofte,
9044: The harde time after the softe:
9045: Be See as thei forth homward wente,
9046: A rage of gret tempeste hem hente;
9047: Juno let bende hire parti bowe,
9048: The Sky wax derk, the wynd gan blowe,
9049: The firy welkne gan to thondre,
9050: As thogh the world scholde al to sondre;
9051: Fro hevene out of the watergates
9052: The reyni Storm fell doun algates
9053: And al here takel made unwelde,
9055: Ther mai men hiere Schipmen crie,
9056: That stode in aunter forto die:
9057: He that behinde sat to stiere
9059: The Schip aros ayein the wawes,
9060: The lodesman hath lost his lawes,
9061: The See bet in on every side:
9063: Bot sette hem al in goddes wille,
9064: Wher he hem wolde save or spille.
9065: And it fell thilke time thus:
9066: Ther was a king, the which Namplus
9067: Was hote, and he a Sone hadde,
9068: At Troie which the Gregois ladde,
9069: As he that was mad Prince of alle,
9070: Til that fortune let him falle:
9073: Of some of hem his deth was cast
9075: His fader, whan he herde it telle,
9076: He swor, if evere his time felle,
9077: He wolde him venge, if that he mihte,
9079: And thus this king thurgh prive hate
9081: For he was noght of such emprise
9082: To vengen him in open wise.
9083: The fame, which goth wyde where,
9084: Makth knowe how that the Gregois were
9086: Fro Troie upon the See be Schipe.
9088: And knew the tydes of the flod,
9089: And sih the wynd blew to the lond,
9090: A gret deceipte anon he fond
9091: Of prive hate, as thou schalt hiere,
9092: Wherof I telle al this matiere.
9093: This king the weder gan beholde,
9094: And wiste wel thei moten holde
9095: Here cours endlong his marche riht,
9096: And made upon the derke nyht
9097: Of grete Schydes and of blockes
9098: Gret fyr ayein the grete rockes,
9099: To schewe upon the helles hihe,
9100: So that the Flete of Grece it sihe.
9101: And so it fell riht as he thoghte:
9102: This Flete, which an havene soghte,
9103: The bryghte fyres sih a ferr,
9104: And thei hem drowen nerr and nerr,
9106: How al that fyr was made for goode,
9107: To schewe wher men scholde aryve,
9109: In Semblant, as men sein, is guile,
9110: And that was proved thilke while;
9111: The Schip, which wende his helpe acroche,
9112: Drof al to pieces on the roche,
9113: And so ther deden ten or twelve;
9115: For ther thei wenden deth ascape,
9116: Withouten help here deth was schape.
9117: Thus thei that comen ferst tofore
9119: Bot thurgh the noise and thurgh the cri
9120: These othre were al war therby;
9121: And whan the dai began to rowe,
9122: Tho mihten thei the sothe knowe,
9123: That wher they wenden frendes finde,
9125: The lond was thanne sone weyved,
9126: Wher that thei hadden be deceived,
9127: And toke hem to the hihe See;
9129: Fro that dai forth and war thei were
9130: Of that thei hadde assaied there.
9131: Mi Sone, hierof thou miht avise
9132: How fraude stant in many wise
9134: Ther is no Scrivein with his enke
9135: Which half the fraude wryte can
9136: That stant in such a maner man:
9137: Forthi the wise men ne demen
9138: The thinges after that thei semen,
9139: Bot after that thei knowe and finde.
9140: The Mirour scheweth in his kinde
9141: As he hadde al the world withinne,
9142: And is in soth nothing therinne;
9143: And so farth Hate for a throwe:
9144: Til he a man hath overthrowe,
9145: Schal noman knowe be his chere
9146: Which is avant, ne which arere.
9147: Forthi, mi Sone, thenke on this.
9148: Mi fader, so I wole ywiss;
9149: And if ther more of Wraththe be,
9151: As ye be youre bokes knowe,
9152: And I the sothe schal beknowe.
9156: And forto telle here names so,
9158: That ben to drede on every side.
9159: Contek, so as the bokes sein,
9164: Fro merci thei ben al unmeete,
9165: And thus ben thei the worste of alle
9166: Of hem whiche unto wraththe falle,
9167: In dede bothe and ek in thoght:
9168: For thei acompte here wraththe at noght,
9169: Bot if ther be schedinge of blod;
9170: And thus lich to a beste wod
9171: Thei knowe noght the god of lif.
9172: Be so thei have or swerd or knif
9174: Of Pite list hem noght to speke;
9175: Non other reson thei ne fonge,
9176: Bot that thei ben of mihtes stronge.
9177: Bot war hem wel in other place,
9179: Bot ther I trowe it schal hem faile,
9180: To whom no merci mihte availe,
9182: That no pite ne mihte hem plie.
9183: Now tell, my Sone. Fader, what?
9184: If thou hast be coupable of that.
9185: Mi fader, nay, Crist me forbiede:
9186: I speke onliche as of the dede,
9187: Of which I nevere was coupable
9189: Bot this is noght to mi matiere
9190: Of schrifte, why we sitten hiere;
9191: For we ben sett to schryve of love,
9194: That as touchende of loves throwe,
9196: Min hertes contek hath non ende,
9197: Bot evere it stant upon debat
9198: To gret desese of myn astat
9199: As for the time that it lasteth.
9201: Hire whiel and is to me so strange,
9202: And that I se sche wol noght change,
9203: Than caste I al the world aboute,
9204: And thenke hou I at home and oute
9205: Have al my time in vein despended,
9206: And se noght how to ben amended,
9208: As he that is welnyh despeired:
9209: For I ne mai no thonk deserve,
9210: And evere I love and evere I serve,
9211: And evere I am aliche nerr.
9212: Thus, for I stonde in such a wer,
9213: I am, as who seith, out of herre;
9214: And thus upon miself the werre
9215: I bringe, and putte out alle pes,
9216: That I fulofte in such a res
9217: Am wery of myn oghne lif.
9218: So that of Contek and of strif
9219: I am beknowe and have ansuerd,
9220: As ye, my fader, now have herd.
9222: With conseil, wherof witt is on,
9225: Will, which hath hope of his acord,
9226: And thus thei bringen up descord.
9228: That I myn herte scholde softe,
9229: And that I scholde will remue
9230: And put him out of retenue,
9231: Or elles holde him under fote:
9232: For as thei sein, if that he mote
9233: His oghne rewle have upon honde,
9234: Ther schal no witt ben understonde.
9235: Of hope also thei tellen this,
9236: That overal, wher that he is,
9237: He set the herte in jeupartie
9239: And is noght trewe of that he seith,
9240: So that in him ther is no feith:
9241: Thus with reson and wit avised
9242: Is will and hope aldai despised.
9243: Reson seith that I scholde leve
9244: To love, wher ther is no leve
9245: To spede, and will seith therayein
9246: That such an herte is to vilein,
9247: Which dar noght love and til he spede,
9248: Let hope serve at such a nede:
9249: He seith ek, where an herte sit
9251: He hath this lyves lust forlore.
9252: And thus myn herte is al totore
9253: Of such a Contek as thei make:
9254: Bot yit I mai noght will forsake,
9255: That he nys Maister of my thoght,
9256: Or that I spede, or spede noght.
9257: Thou dost, my Sone, ayein the riht;
9258: Bot love is of so gret a miht,
9260: So miht thou thee the betre excuse.
9261: And natheles thou schalt be lerned
9262: That will scholde evere be governed
9263: Of reson more than of kinde,
9264: Wherof a tale write I finde.
9265: A Philosophre of which men tolde
9266: Ther was whilom be daies olde,
9268: So old he was that he ne mihte
9269: The world travaile, and for the beste
9270: He schop him forto take his reste,
9271: And duelte at hom in such a wise,
9272: That nyh his hous he let devise
9274: To sette a tonne in such degre,
9275: That he it mihte torne aboute;
9276: Wherof on hed was taken oute,
9278: And torne himself so as he wolde,
9279: To take their and se the hevene
9280: And deme of the planetes sevene,
9281: As he which cowthe mochel what.
9282: And thus fulofte there he sat
9286: As thing which scholde so betyde,
9287: Whan he was set ther as him liste
9288: To loke upon the Sonne ariste,
9290: It fell ther cam ridende nyh
9292: And as he caste his yhe aboute,
9293: He sih this Tonne, and what it mente
9294: He wolde wite, and thider sente
9295: A knyht, be whom he mihte it knowe,
9296: And he himself that ilke throwe
9298: This kniht after the kinges wille
9299: With spore made his hors to gon
9300: And to the tonne he cam anon,
9301: Wher that he fond a man of Age,
9302: And he him tolde the message,
9303: Such as the king him hadde bede,
9304: And axeth why in thilke stede
9305: The Tonne stod, and what it was.
9306: And he, which understod the cas,
9307: Sat stille and spak no word ayein.
9308: The kniht bad speke and seith, "Vilein,
9309: Thou schalt me telle, er that I go;
9310: It is thi king which axeth so."
9312: "What is he thanne?" seith the kniht,
9313: "Is he thi man?" "That seie I noght,"
9314: Quod he, "bot this I am bethoght,
9315: Mi mannes man hou that he is."
9317: The kniht him seith, and was riht wroth,
9318: And to the king ayein he goth
9319: And tolde him how this man ansuerde.
9320: The king, whan he this tale herde,
9321: Bad that thei scholden alle abyde,
9322: For he himself wol thider ryde.
9323: And whan he cam tofore the tonne,
9324: He hath his tale thus begonne:
9326: Quod he, "Such on as thou sest now."
9327: The king, which hadde wordes wise,
9329: Bot seith, "Mi fader, I thee preie
9330: That thou me wolt the cause seie,
9331: How that I am thi mannes man."
9332: "Sire king," quod he, "and that I can,
9333: If that thou wolt." "Yis," seith the king.
9334: Quod he, "This is the sothe thing:
9336: And knew what thing was evel and good,
9337: The will which of my bodi moeveth,
9338: Whos werkes that the god reproeveth,
9340: As him which stant under the lore
9341: Of reson, whos soubgit he is,
9342: So that he mai noght don amis:
9343: And thus be weie of covenant
9344: Will is my man and my servant,
9345: And evere hath ben and evere schal.
9346: And thi will is thi principal,
9347: And hath the lordschipe of thi witt,
9348: So that thou cowthest nevere yit
9349: Take o dai reste of thi labour;
9351: Of worldes good, which mai noght laste,
9353: Wher thou no reson hast to winne:
9354: And thus thi will is cause of Sinne,
9355: And is thi lord, to whom thou servest,
9357: The king of that he thus answerde
9358: Was nothing wroth, bot whanne he herde
9359: The hihe wisdom which he seide,
9360: With goodly wordes this he preide,
9361: That he him wolde telle his name.
9364: Tho was the king riht glad withalle,
9365: For he hadde often herd tofore
9366: What man he was, so that therfore
9368: Now schal thi grete witt be sene;
9369: For thou schalt of my yifte have
9370: What worldes thing that thou wolt crave."
9371: Quod he, "Thanne hove out of mi Sonne,
9372: And let it schyne into mi Tonne;
9373: For thou benymst me thilke yifte,
9374: Which lith noght in thi miht to schifte:
9375: Non other good of thee me nedeth."
9376: This king, whom every contre dredeth,
9377: Lo, thus he was enformed there:
9378: Wherof, my Sone, thou miht lere
9379: How that thi will schal noght be lieved,
9380: Where it is noght of wit relieved.
9381: And thou hast seid thiself er this
9382: How that thi will thi maister is;
9383: Thurgh which thin hertes thoght withinne
9384: Is evere of Contek to beginne,
9385: So that it is gretli to drede
9387: For love is of a wonder kinde,
9388: And hath hise wittes ofte blinde,
9389: That thei fro mannes reson falle;
9390: Bot whan that it is so befalle
9391: That will schal the corage lede,
9392: In loves cause it is to drede:
9395: I rede a tale, and telleth this:
9398: Of worthi folk with many a route
9400: Among the whiche tuo ther were
9401: Above alle othre noble and grete,
9403: So nyh togedre, as it was sene,
9404: That ther was nothing hem betwene,
9405: Bot wow to wow and wall to wall.
9406: This o lord hadde in special
9408: In al the toun was non his pier:
9409: That other hadde a dowhter eke,
9410: In al the lond that forto seke
9411: Men wisten non so faire as sche.
9412: And fell so, as it scholde be,
9413: This faire dowhter nyh this Sone
9415: Cupide hath so the thinges schape,
9416: That thei ne mihte his hand ascape,
9417: That he his fyr on hem ne caste:
9419: To folwe thilke lore and suie
9420: Which nevere man yit miht eschuie;
9421: And that was love, as it is happed,
9422: Which hath here hertes so betrapped,
9423: That thei be alle weies seche
9424: How that thei mihten winne a speche,
9426: Who loveth wel, it mai noght misse,
9427: And namely whan ther be tuo
9428: Of on acord, how so it go,
9429: Bot if that thei som weie finde;
9430: For love is evere of such a kinde
9431: And hath his folk so wel affaited,
9432: That howso that it be awaited,
9433: Ther mai noman the pourpos lette:
9434: And thus betwen hem tuo thei sette
9435: And hole upon a wall to make,
9436: Thurgh which thei have her conseil take
9437: At alle times, whan thei myhte.
9439: And he whom that sche loveth hote
9441: So longe here lecoun thei recorden,
9444: Al one out fro the tounes ende,
9445: Wher was a welle under a Tree;
9446: And who cam ferst, or sche or he,
9448: So it befell the nyhtes tide
9451: Goth thurgh the large toun unknowe,
9452: Til that sche cam withinne a throwe
9453: Wher that sche liketh forto duelle,
9455: Which was also the Forest nyh.
9456: Wher sche comende a Leoun syh
9457: Into the feld to take his preie,
9458: In haste and sche tho fledde aweie,
9460: For feere and let hire wympel falle
9461: Nyh to the welle upon therbage.
9462: This Leoun in his wilde rage
9463: A beste, which that he fond oute,
9464: Hath slain, and with his blodi snoute,
9465: Whan he hath eten what he wolde,
9466: To drynke of thilke stremes colde
9467: Cam to the welle, where he fond
9468: The wympel, which out of hire hond
9469: Was falle, and he it hath todrawe,
9471: And thanne he strawhte him forto drinke
9473: And after that out of the plein
9474: He torneth to the wode ayein.
9476: Bot as a bridd which were in Mue
9477: Withinne a buissh sche kepte hire clos
9478: So stille that sche noght aros;
9480: And fell, whil that sche there lay,
9482: Unto the welle, and be the Mone
9483: He fond hire wimpel blodi there.
9484: Cam nevere yit to mannes Ere
9487: A mannes herte, as it tho dede
9488: To him, which in the same stede
9492: That sche be ded: and sodeinly
9493: His swerd al nakid out he breide
9494: In his folhaste, and thus he seide:
9496: So it is resoun that I die,
9497: As sche is ded be cause of me."
9498: And with that word upon his kne
9499: He fell, and to the goddes alle
9500: Up to the hevene he gan to calle,
9501: And preide, sithen it was so
9502: That he may noght his love as tho
9503: Have in this world, that of her grace
9504: He miht hire have in other place,
9505: For hiere wolde he noght abide,
9506: He seith: bot as it schal betide,
9507: The Pomel of his swerd to grounde
9508: He sette, and thurgh his herte a wounde
9509: He made up to the bare hilte:
9510: And in this wise himself he spilte
9511: With his folhaste and deth he nam;
9512: For sche withinne a while cam,
9513: Wher he lai ded upon his knif.
9514: So wofull yit was nevere lif
9515: As Tisbee was, whan sche him sih:
9516: Sche mihte noght o word on hih
9517: Speke oute, for hire herte schette,
9518: That of hir lif no pris sche sette,
9519: Bot ded swounende doun sche fell.
9520: Til after, whanne it so befell
9521: That sche out of hire traunce awok,
9522: With many a wofull pitous lok
9523: Hire yhe alwei among sche caste
9524: Upon hir love, and ate laste
9525: Sche cawhte breth and seide thus:
9527: Goddesse of love, and thou, Cupide,
9528: Which loves cause hast forto guide,
9529: I wot now wel that ye be blinde,
9530: Of thilke unhapp which I now finde
9531: Only betwen my love and me.
9532: This Piramus, which hiere I se
9534: For he youre heste hath kept and served,
9535: And was yong and I bothe also:
9536: Helas, why do ye with ous so?
9537: Ye sette oure herte bothe afyre,
9538: And maden ous such thing desire
9539: Wherof that we no skile cowthe;
9540: Bot thus oure freisshe lusti yowthe
9542: Which thing mai nevere ben amended:
9543: For as of me this wol I seie,
9544: That me is levere forto deie
9545: Than live after this sorghful day."
9546: And with this word, where as he lay,
9547: Hire love in armes sche embraseth,
9548: Hire oghne deth and so pourchaseth
9549: That now sche wepte and nou sche kiste,
9550: Til ate laste, er sche it wiste,
9551: So gret a sorwe is to hire falle,
9553: As sche which mihte it noght asterte,
9554: The swerdes point ayein hire herte
9555: Sche sette, and fell doun therupon,
9556: Wherof that sche was ded anon:
9557: And thus bothe on o swerd bledende
9559: Now thou, mi Sone, hast herd this tale,
9560: Bewar that of thin oghne bale
9561: Thou be noght cause in thi folhaste,
9562: And kep that thou thi witt ne waste
9565: Mai falle: and if thou have so thoght
9566: Er this, tell on and hyde it noght.
9568: Mi conscience I woll noght hyde,
9569: How that for love of pure wo
9570: I have ben ofte moeved so,
9571: That with my wisshes if I myhte,
9572: A thousand times, I yow plyhte,
9573: I hadde storven in a day;
9574: And therof I me schryve may,
9575: Though love fully me ne slowh,
9576: Mi will to deie was ynowh,
9577: So am I of my will coupable:
9578: And yit is sche noght merciable,
9579: Which mai me yive lif and hele.
9580: Bot that hir list noght with me dele,
9581: I wot be whos conseil it is,
9582: And him wolde I long time er this,
9583: And yit I wolde and evere schal,
9585: The gold of nyne kinges londes
9586: Ne scholde him save fro myn hondes,
9587: In my pouer if that he were;
9588: Bot yit him stant of me no fere
9589: For noght that evere I can manace.
9590: He is the hindrere of mi grace,
9591: Til he be ded I mai noght spede;
9592: So mot I nedes taken hiede
9593: And schape how that he were aweie,
9594: If I therto mai finde a weie.
9595: Mi Sone, tell me now forthi,
9597: That thou manacest to be ded.

10289: The lawe stod er we were bore,
10290: How that a kinges swerd is bore
10291: In signe that he schal defende
10292: His trewe poeple and make an ende

10294: Lo thus, my Sone, to socoure
10295: The lawe and comun riht to winne,
10296: A man mai sle withoute Sinne,
10297: And do therof a gret almesse,
10299: And over this for his contre
10300: In time of werre a man is fre
10301: Himself, his hous and ek his lond
10303: And slen, if that he mai no bet,
10304: After the lawe which is set.
10305: Now, fader, thanne I you beseche
10306: Of hem that dedly werres seche
10307: In worldes cause and scheden blod,
10308: If such an homicide is good.
10311: Als ferforth as my wit arecheth
10312: And as the pleine lawe techeth,
10313: I woll thee telle in evidence,
10315: The hihe god of his justice
10318: Be Moiµses as it was bede.
10319: Whan goddes Sone also was bore,
10320: He sende hise anglis doun therfore,
10322: Pes to the men of welwillinge
10323: In erthe be among ous here.
10324: So forto speke in this matiere
10326: Ther schal no dedly werre be:
10327: And ek nature it hath defended
10328: And in hir lawe pes comended,
10329: Which is the chief of mannes welthe,
10330: Of mannes lif, of mannes helthe.
10331: Bot dedly werre hath his covine
10333: Of poverte and of alle wo,
10334: Wherof this world we blamen so,
10335: Which now the werre hath under fote,
10336: Til god himself therof do bote.
10337: For alle thing which god hath wroght
10338: In Erthe, werre it bringth to noght:
10339: The cherche is brent, the priest is slain,
10340: The wif, the maide is ek forlain,
10341: The lawe is lore and god unserved:
10342: I not what mede he hath deserved
10344: If that he do it forto winne,
10345: Ferst to acompte his grete cost
10346: Forth with the folk that he hath lost,
10348: Ther schal he finde no winnynge;
10349: And if he do it to pourchace
10350: The hevene mede, of such a grace
10351: I can noght speke, and natheles
10352: Crist hath comanded love and pes,
10353: And who that worcheth the revers,
10354: I trowe his mede is ful divers.
10355: And sithen thanne that we finde
10356: That werres in here oghne kinde

10358: And ek thei bringen in poverte
10359: Of worldes good, it is merveile
10360: Among the men what it mai eyle,
10361: That thei a pes ne conne sette.
10362: I trowe Senne be the lette,
10363: And every mede of Senne is deth;
10364: So wot I nevere hou that it geth:
10365: Bot we that ben of o believe
10366: Among ousself, this wolde I lieve,
10367: That betre it were pes to chese,
10368: Than so be double weie lese.
10369: I not if that it now so stonde,
10370: Bot this a man mai understonde,
10371: Who that these olde bokes redeth,
10372: That coveitise is on which ledeth,

10410: For as the trew man to the plowh

10460: Bot thi richesse and my poverte

10465: A povere man to gret richesse

10472: Wherof my will is, that thou stonde

10475: He hath him terme of lif withholde,
10476: The mor and for he schal ben holde,

10478: Which afterward was of his hond
10479: And orped kniht in many a stede,
10480: And gret prouesce of armes dede,
10482: And in this wise thei acorden,

10488: It is gret wonder that men caste
10489: Here herte upon such wrong to winne,
10490: Wher no beyete mai ben inne,
10491: And doth desese on every side:
10492: Bot whan reson is put aside
10494: The faucon which that fleth ramage
10495: And soeffreth nothing in the weie,
10496: Wherof that he mai take his preie,
10497: Is noght mor set upon ravine,
10498: Than thilke man which his covine
10499: Hath set in such a maner wise:
10500: For al the world ne mai suffise
10501: To will which is noght resonable.
10503: Lich to this point of which I meene,
10505: Which hadde set al his entente,
10506: So as fortune with him wente,
10507: That reson mihte him non governe,
10508: Bot of his will he was so sterne,
10509: That al the world he overran
10510: And what him list he tok and wan.
10512: Whan that he was ful conquerour,
10513: And hadde his wilful pourpos wonne

10518: As he which was hol lord and Sire,
10522: And as he hath the world mistimed
10523: Noght as he scholde with his wit,

10526: And he which riche was ynowh
10527: This dai, tomorwe he hadde noght:
10528: And in such wise as he hath wroght
10530: His werre he fond thanne endeles,
10532: He was. Lo now, for what profit
10533: Of werre it helpeth forto ryde,
10535: To sle the worldes men aboute,
10537: For every lif which reson can
10538: Oghth wel to knowe that a man
10540: Lich to these othre bestes die,

10544: The lif that he mai noght restore.

10546: Be wel avised, I thee preie,

10571: And that mai proven in the dede;

10601: To werre ech other and to slee.

10650: For after that the bokes telle,
10651: To seche in al this worldesriche,
10652: Men schal noght finde upon his liche

10654: And sithen kinde hath such a weie,
10655: Thanne is it wonder of a man,

10661: Ne kinde, and that is noght honeste,

10664: Solyns spekth of a wonder kinde,
10665: And seith of fowhles ther is on,
10666: Which hath a face of blod and bon

10669: As he which is a fowhl of preie,
10670: That he a man finde in his weie,
10671: He wol him slen, if that he mai:
10673: Whan he hath eten al his felle,
10674: And that schal be beside a welle,
10675: In which whan he wol drinke take,
10676: Of his visage and seth the make

10678: Of his misdede, and it forthenketh
10679: So gretly, that for pure sorwe
10680: He liveth noght til on the morwe.
10681: Be this ensample it mai well suie
10683: For evere is merci good to take,
10684: Bot if the lawe it hath forsake
10686: For ofte time I have herd sein
10688: That thei som while here cause ladden

10694: Where it was used, lacke grace.

10699: And ben most mihti forto grieve,
10702: As be ensample a man mai knowe.
10703: He mai noght failen of his mede

10705: In a Cronique and finde thus.

10816: Mi goode fader, be your leve

10818: For I have in you such a trist,
