10822: Mi Sone, art thou coupable of Slowthe
10823: In eny point which to him longeth?
10824: My fader, of tho pointz me longeth
10825: To wite pleinly what thei meene,
10826: So that I mai me schrive cleene.
10827: Now herkne, I schal the pointz devise;
10829: For schrifte stant of no value
10830: To him that wol him noght vertue
10831: To leve of vice the folie:
10832: For word is wynd, bot the maistrie
10833: Is that a man himself defende
10834: Of thing which is noght to comende,
10836: And natheles, so as I may
10838: The pointz of Slowthe thou schalt knowe.
10840: After the cause of mannes dede,
10841: The ferste point of Slowthe I calle
10842: Lachesce, and is the chief of alle,
10843: And hath this propreliche of kinde,
10845: Of that he mihte do now hier
10846: He tarieth al the longe yer,
10848: And so he wol his time borwe,
10850: That whan he weneth have an ende,
10851: Thanne is he ferthest to beginne.
10852: Thus bringth he many a meschief inne
10853: Unwar, til that he be meschieved,
10854: And may noght thanne be relieved.
10855: And riht so nowther mor ne lesse
10856: It stant of love and of lachesce:
10857: Som time he slowtheth in a day
10858: That he nevere after gete mai.
10859: Now, Sone, as of this ilke thing,
10861: That thou to love hast don er this,
10862: Tell on. Mi goode fader, yis.
10863: As of lachesce I am beknowe
10864: That I mai stonde upon his rowe,
10865: As I that am clad of his suite:
10866: For whanne I thoghte mi poursuite
10867: To make, and therto sette a day
10868: To speke unto the swete May,
10870: And bar on hond it was no wit
10871: Ne time forto speke as tho.
10872: Thus with his tales to and fro
10873: Mi time in tariinge he drowh:
10874: Whan ther was time good ynowh,
10875: He seide, "An other time is bettre;
10876: Thou schalt mowe senden hire a lettre,
10877: And per cas wryte more plein
10878: Than thou be Mowthe durstest sein."
10879: Thus have I lete time slyde
10880: For Slowthe, and kepte noght my tide,
10881: So that lachesce with his vice
10882: Fulofte hath mad my wit so nyce,
10883: That what I thoghte speke or do
10884: With tariinge he hield me so,
10885: Til whanne I wolde and mihte noght.
10886: I not what thing was in my thoght,
10887: Or it was drede, or it was schame;
10888: Bot evere in ernest and in game
10889: I wot ther is long time passed.
10890: Bot yit is noght the love lassed,
10891: Which I unto mi ladi have;
10892: For thogh my tunge is slowh to crave
10893: At alle time, as I have bede,
10894: Min herte stant evere in o stede
10896: The which I mai noght yit embrace.
10897: And god wot that is malgre myn;
10898: For this I wot riht wel a fin,
10899: Mi grace comth so selde aboute,
10900: That is the Slowthe of which I doute
10901: Mor than of al the remenant
10903: And thus as touchende of lachesce,
10904: As I have told, I me confesse
10905: To you, mi fader, and beseche
10906: That furthermor ye wol me teche;
10907: And if ther be to this matiere
10909: How I mai do lachesce aweie,
10910: That ye it wolden telle I preie.
10911: To wisse thee, my Sone, and rede,
10912: Among the tales whiche I rede,
10914: Now herkne, and I wol tellen on.

10961: And whan sche sih him tarie so,

10982: In this matiere an other spieche,
10983: In a Cronique I finde write
10984: A tale which is good to wite.
10986: Upon the Siege among the pres
10987: Of hem that worthi knihtes were
10989: In thilke time a man mai se
10991: Which was to him his trewe wif,
10993: Wherof to Troie sche him sende
10994: Hire will be lettre, thus spekende:
10996: It is and hath ben evere so,
10997: That wher a womman is al one,
10998: It makth a man in his persone
11000: In hope that sche wolde bowe
11001: To such thing as his wille were,
11002: Whil that hire lord were elleswhere.
11003: And of miself I telle this;
11004: For it so longe passed is,
11005: Sithe ferst than ye fro home wente,
11006: That welnyh every man his wente
11007: To there I am, whil ye ben oute,
11008: Hath mad, and ech of hem aboute,
11009: Which love can, my love secheth,
11010: With gret preiere and me besecheth:
11012: That if thei mihten come in place,
11013: Wher that thei mihte here wille have,
11014: Ther is nothing me scholde save,
11015: That thei ne wolde werche thinges;
11017: That ye ben ded, and some sein
11019: To love a newe and leve me.
11020: Bot hou as evere that it be,
11021: I thonke unto the goddes alle,
11022: As yit for oght that is befalle
11023: Mai noman do my chekes rede:
11024: Bot natheles it is to drede,
11029: A lettre unto hire lord hath write,
11030: And preyde him that he wolde wite
11031: And thenke hou that sche was al his,
11032: And that he tarie noght in this,
11033: Bot that he wolde his love aquite,
11034: To hire ayeinward and noght wryte,
11035: Bot come himself in alle haste,
11036: That he non other paper waste;
11037: So that he kepe and holde his trowthe
11039: Unto hire lord and love liege
11040: To Troie, wher the grete Siege
11041: Was leid, this lettre was conveied.
11042: And he, which wisdom hath pourveied
11043: Of al that to reson belongeth,
11045: And whan he hath it overrad,
11046: In part he was riht inly glad,
11047: And ek in part he was desesed:
11048: Bot love his herte hath so thorghsesed
11051: Which he can take on other side,
11052: He mai noght flitt his herte aside
11053: Fro that his wif him hadde enformed;
11055: With al the wille of his corage
11056: To schape and take the viage
11057: Homward, what time that he mai:
11058: So that him thenketh of a day
11059: A thousand yer, til he mai se
11061: Which he desireth most of alle.
11062: And whan the time is so befalle
11063: That Troie was destruid and brent,
11065: Bot goth him home in alle hihe,
11066: Wher that he fond tofore his yhe
11067: His worthi wif in good astat:
11068: And thus was cessed the debat
11069: Of love, and Slowthe was excused,
11070: Which doth gret harm, where it is used,
11071: And hindreth many a cause honeste.
11072: For of the grete Clerc Grossteste
11073: I rede how besy that he was
11074: Upon clergie an Hed of bras
11075: To forge, and make it forto telle
11078: He leyde, bot for the lachesse
11079: Of half a Minut of an houre,
11080: Fro ferst that he began laboure
11081: He loste all that he hadde do.
11083: In loves cause who is slow,
11084: That he withoute under the wow
11086: Which mihte, if that he hadde wold
11087: His time kept, have be withinne.
11088: Bot Slowthe mai no profit winne,
11089: Bot he mai singe in his karole
11090: How Latewar cam to the Dole,
11091: Wher he no good receive mihte.
11092: And that was proved wel be nyhte
11094: Whan thilke lord cam forto wyve:
11095: For that here oyle was aweie
11096: To lihte here lampes in his weie,
11097: Here Slowthe broghte it so aboute,
11098: Fro him that thei ben schet withoute.
11099: Wherof, my Sone, be thou war,
11100: Als ferforth as I telle dar.
11102: And if thou be noght wel affaited
11105: Thou miht noght of thiself ben able
11106: To winne love or make it stable,
11107: All thogh thou mihtest love achieve.
11108: Mi fader, that I mai wel lieve.
11109: Bot me was nevere assigned place,
11110: Wher yit to geten eny grace,
11111: Ne me was non such time apointed;
11112: For thanne I wolde I were unjoynted
11113: Of every lime that I have,
11114: If I ne scholde kepe and save
11115: Min houre bothe and ek my stede,
11116: If my ladi it hadde bede.
11118: Than grante such a time assised;
11120: Ther hath be no defalte I gesse
11121: Of time lost, if that I mihte:
11122: Bot yit hire liketh noght alyhte
11123: Upon no lure which I caste;
11124: For ay the more I crie faste,
11125: The lasse hire liketh forto hiere.
11126: So forto speke of this matiere,
11127: I seche that I mai noght finde,
11128: I haste and evere I am behinde,
11129: And wot noght what it mai amounte.
11131: Which ye be sett to examine
11133: Sey what your beste conseil is.
11134: Mi Sone, my conseil is this:
11135: Hou so it stonde of time go,
11137: That no Lachesce in the be founde:
11138: For Slowthe is mihti to confounde
11139: The spied of every mannes werk.
11140: For many a vice, as seith the clerk,
11142: Of suche as make a man mishappe,
11143: To pleigne and telle of hadde I wist.
11144: And therupon if that thee list
11145: To knowe of Slowthes cause more,
11147: Ther is a vice full grevable
11148: To him which is therof coupable,
11149: And stant of alle vertu bare,
11151: Touchende of Slowthe in his degre,
11153: Which is to seie in this langage,
11154: He that hath litel of corage
11155: And dar no mannes werk beginne:
11156: So mai he noght be resoun winne;
11157: For who that noght dar undertake,
11158: Be riht he schal no profit take.
11159: Bot of this vice the nature
11161: Him lacketh bothe word and dede,
11162: Wherof he scholde his cause spede:
11164: For evere he hath drede upon honde:
11165: Al is peril that he schal seie,
11166: Him thenkth the wolf is in the weie,
11169: And feigneth cause of pure drede,
11170: And evere he faileth ate nede,
11171: Til al be spilt that he with deleth.
11172: He hath the sor which noman heleth,
11173: The which is cleped lack of herte;
11174: Thogh every grace aboute him sterte,
11175: He wol noght ones stere his fot;
11176: So that be resoun lese he mot,
11177: That wol noght auntre forto winne.
11178: And so forth, Sone, if we beginne
11179: To speke of love and his servise,
11180: Ther ben truantz in such a wise,
11181: That lacken herte, whan best were
11182: To speke of love, and riht for fere
11183: Thei wexen doumb and dar noght telle,
11184: Withoute soun as doth the belle,
11185: Which hath no claper forto chyme;
11186: And riht so thei as for the tyme
11188: Of love, and dar nothing beseche;
11189: And thus thei lese and winne noght.
11190: Forthi, my Sone, if thou art oght
11191: Coupable as touchende of this Slowthe,
11192: Schrif thee therof and tell me trowthe.
11193: Mi fader, I am al beknowe
11194: That I have ben on of tho slowe,
11195: As forto telle in loves cas.
11196: Min herte is yit and evere was,
11197: As thogh the world scholde al tobreke,
11198: So ferful, that I dar noght speke
11199: Of what pourpos that I have nome,
11200: Whan I toward mi ladi come,
11201: Bot let it passe and overgo.
11203: For after that a man poursuieth
11205: Fulofte and yifth hire happi chance
11207: To preie love and to beseche;
11208: As be ensample I schal thee teche.
11209: I finde hou whilom ther was on,
11211: Which was a lusti man of yowthe:
11212: The werkes of entaile he cowthe
11213: Above alle othre men as tho;
11214: And thurgh fortune it fell him so,
11215: As he whom love schal travaile,
11216: He made an ymage of entaile
11217: Lich to a womman in semblance
11219: So fair yit nevere was figure.
11221: Sche semeth, for of yvor whyt
11222: He hath hire wroght of such delit,
11223: That sche was rody on the cheke
11224: And red on bothe hire lippes eke;
11226: For with a goodly lok sche smyleth,
11229: With al the herte of his corage
11230: His love upon this faire ymage
11231: He sette, and hire of love preide;
11232: Bot sche no word ayeinward seide.
11233: The longe day, what thing he dede,
11234: This ymage in the same stede
11235: Was evere bi, that ate mete
11236: He wolde hire serve and preide hire ete,
11237: And putte unto hire mowth the cuppe;
11238: And whan the bord was taken uppe,
11239: He hath hire into chambre nome,
11240: And after, whan the nyht was come,
11241: He leide hire in his bed al nakid.
11242: He was forwept, he was forwakid,
11243: He keste hire colde lippes ofte,
11244: And wissheth that thei weren softe,
11245: And ofte he rouneth in hire Ere,
11246: And ofte his arm now hier now there
11247: He leide, as he hir wolde embrace,
11248: And evere among he axeth grace,
11249: As thogh sche wiste what he mente:
11250: And thus himself he gan tormente
11251: With such desese of loves peine,
11252: That noman mihte him more peine.
11253: Bot how it were, of his penance
11255: Fro dai to nyht, and preith so longe,
11257: Which Venus of hire grace herde;
11258: Be nyhte and whan that he worst ferde,
11259: And it lay in his nakede arm,
11260: The colde ymage he fieleth warm
11261: Of fleissh and bon and full of lif.
11262: Lo, thus he wan a lusti wif,
11263: Which obeissant was at his wille;
11264: And if he wolde have holde him stille
11265: And nothing spoke, he scholde have failed:
11266: Bot for he hath his word travailed
11267: And dorste speke, his love he spedde,
11268: And hadde al that he wolde abedde.
11269: For er thei wente thanne atwo,
11270: A knave child betwen hem two
11271: Thei gete, which was after hote
11272: Paphus, of whom yit hath the note
11274: Men clepe, and of his name it ros.
11275: Be this ensample thou miht finde
11276: That word mai worche above kinde.
11277: Forthi, my Sone, if that thou spare
11278: To speke, lost is al thi fare,
11279: For Slowthe bringth in alle wo.
11280: And over this to loke also,
11281: The god of love is favorable
11282: To hem that ben of love stable,
11283: And many a wonder hath befalle:
11285: If that thee list to taken hede,
11286: Therof a solein tale I rede,
11287: Which I schal telle in remembraunce
11288: Upon the sort of loves chaunce.
11289: The king Ligdus upon a strif
11291: Which thanne was with childe grete;
11292: He swor it scholde noght be lete,
11293: That if sche have a dowhter bore,
11294: That it ne scholde be forlore
11295: And slain, wherof sche sory was.
11296: So it befell upon this cas,
11299: Which of childinge is the goddesse,
11300: Cam forto helpe in that destresse,
11301: Til that this lady was al smal,
11302: And hadde a dowhter forth withal;
11303: Which the goddesse in alle weie
11304: Bad kepe, and that thei scholden seie
11305: It were a Sone: and thus Iphis
11306: Thei namede him, and upon this
11307: The fader was mad so to wene.
11308: And thus in chambre with the qweene
11311: Riht as a kinges Sone scholde.
11312: Til after, as fortune it wolde,
11313: Whan it was of a ten yer age,
11316: Which Iante hihte, and ofte abedde
11317: These children leien, sche and sche,
11318: Whiche of on age bothe be.
11319: So that withinne time of yeeres,
11324: Constreigneth hem, so that thei use
11325: Thing which to hem was al unknowe;
11327: Tok pite for the grete love,
11328: And let do sette kinde above,
11329: So that hir lawe mai ben used,
11330: And thei upon here lust excused.
11332: Than thing which stant ayein the lore
11333: Of that nature in kinde hath sett:
11337: Whan that he syh the time best,
11338: That ech of hem hath other kest,
11340: Wherof the kinde love he wan
11341: Of lusti yonge Iante his wif;
11342: And tho thei ladde a merie lif,
11343: Which was to kinde non offence.
11344: And thus to take an evidence,
11348: Thing which that is to love due.
11349: Wherof, my Sone, in this matiere
11353: Of love, if that ther be no Slowthe.
11354: I dar wel seie be mi trowthe,
11355: Als fer as I my witt can seche,
11356: Mi fader, as for lacke of speche,
11357: Bot so as I me schrof tofore,
11358: Ther is non other time lore,
11360: To lette love of his miracle,
11361: Which I beseche day and nyht.
11362: Bot, fader, so as it is riht
11363: In forme of schrifte to beknowe
11364: What thing belongeth to the slowe,
11366: If ther be forthere eny weie
11368: Mi Sone, ye, of this office
11371: So that he can no wit withholde
11372: In thing which he to kepe is holde,
11374: And who that most upon him lieveth,
11375: Whan that hise wittes ben so weyved,
11376: He mai full lihtly be deceived.
11377: To serve Accidie in his office,
11378: Ther is of Slowthe an other vice,
11380: That noght mai in his herte impresse
11381: Of vertu which reson hath sett,
11382: So clene his wittes he foryet.
11383: For in the tellinge of his tale
11384: Nomore his herte thanne his male
11386: Wherof he scholde his wit enforme
11387: As thanne, and yit ne wot he why.
11388: Thus is his pourpos noght forthi
11389: Forlore of that he wolde bidde,
11390: And skarsly if he seith the thridde
11391: To love of that he hadde ment:
11392: Thus many a lovere hath be schent.
11393: Tell on therfore, hast thou be oon
11394: Of hem that Slowthe hath so begon?
11395: Ye, fader, ofte it hath be so,
11396: That whanne I am mi ladi fro
11398: Than cast I many a newe lawe
11399: And al the world torne up so doun,
11400: And so recorde I mi lecoun
11402: What I to hire telle schal,
11403: Riht al the matiere of mi tale:
11404: Bot al nys worth a note schale;
11405: For whanne I come ther sche is,
11406: I have it al foryete ywiss;
11407: Of that I thoghte forto telle
11408: I can noght thanne unethes spelle
11409: That I wende altherbest have rad,
11410: So sore I am of hire adrad.
11411: For as a man that sodeinli
11412: A gost behelde, so fare I;
11413: So that for feere I can noght gete
11414: Mi witt, bot I miself foryete,
11415: That I wot nevere what I am,
11416: Ne whider I schal, ne whenne I cam,
11417: Bot muse as he that were amased.
11418: Lich to the bok in which is rased
11419: The lettre, and mai nothing be rad,
11421: That what as evere I thoghte have spoken,
11422: It is out fro myn herte stoken,
11423: And stonde, as who seith, doumb and def,
11424: That all nys worth an yvy lef,
11425: Of that I wende wel have seid.
11426: And ate laste I make abreid,
11427: Caste up myn hed and loke aboute,
11428: Riht as a man that were in doute
11429: And wot noght wher he schal become.
11430: Thus am I ofte al overcome,
11431: Ther as I wende best to stonde:
11433: And am in other place al one,
11434: I make many a wofull mone
11436: "Ha fol, wher was thin herte tho,
11437: Whan thou thi worthi ladi syhe?
11438: Were thou afered of hire yhe?
11439: For of hire hand ther is no drede:
11440: So wel I knowe hir wommanhede,
11441: That in hire is nomore oultrage
11442: Than in a child of thre yeer age.
11443: Whi hast thou drede of so good on,
11445: That in hire is no violence
11448: Ha, nyce herte, fy for schame]
11449: Ha, couard herte of love unlered,
11450: Wherof art thou so sore afered,
11451: That thou thi tunge soffrest frese,
11452: And wolt thi goode wordes lese,
11453: Whan thou hast founde time and space?
11455: Whan thou thiself darst axe non,
11456: Bot al thou hast foryete anon?"
11457: And thus despute I loves lore,
11458: Bot help ne finde I noght the more,
11459: Bot stomble upon myn oghne treine
11460: And make an ekinge of my peine.
11461: For evere whan I thenke among
11462: How al is on miself along,
11463: I seie, "O fol of alle foles,
11464: Thou farst as he betwen tuo stoles
11465: That wolde sitte and goth to grounde.
11466: It was ne nevere schal be founde,
11468: That man scholde any cause spede."
11469: And thus, myn holi fader diere,
11470: Toward miself, as ye mai hiere,
11473: That mai be take of mannes thoght,
11474: Min herte takth, and is thorghsoght
11475: To thenken evere upon that swete
11477: For what so falle, or wel or wo,
11479: Wher so I lawhe or so I loure:
11480: Noght half the Minut of an houre
11481: Ne mihte I lete out of my mende,
11482: Bot if I thoghte upon that hende.
11483: Therof me schal no Slowthe lette,
11484: Til deth out of this world me fette,
11485: Althogh I hadde on such a Ring,
11488: Whan that he Tharbis weddid hade.
11490: The name, and that was be resoun
11491: That where it on a finger sat,
11492: Anon his love he so foryat,
11493: As thogh he hadde it nevere knowe:
11494: And so it fell that ilke throwe,
11495: Whan Tharbis hadde it on hire hond,
11496: No knowlechinge of him sche fond,
11497: Bot al was clene out of memoire,
11498: As men mai rede in his histoire;
11499: And thus he wente quit away,
11500: That nevere after that ilke day
11501: Sche thoghte that ther was such on;
11503: Bot in good feith so mai noght I:
11504: For sche is evere faste by,
11505: So nyh that sche myn herte toucheth,
11506: That for nothing that Slowthe voucheth
11507: I mai foryete hire, lief ne loth;
11508: For overal, where as sche goth,
11510: Thus mai I seie withoute doute,
11511: For bet, for wers, for oght, for noght,
11512: Sche passeth nevere fro my thoght;
11513: Bot whanne I am ther as sche is,
11514: Min herte, as I you saide er this,
11515: Som time of hire is sore adrad,
11516: And som time it is overglad,
11517: Al out of reule and out of space.
11518: For whan I se hir goodli face
11519: And thenke upon hire hihe pris,
11520: As thogh I were in Paradis,
11521: I am so ravisht of the syhte,
11522: That speke unto hire I ne myhte
11523: As for the time, thogh I wolde:
11524: For I ne mai my wit unfolde
11525: To finde o word of that I mene,
11526: Bot al it is foryete clene;
11527: And thogh I stonde there a myle,
11528: Al is foryete for the while,
11529: A tunge I have and wordes none.
11530: And thus I stonde and thenke al one
11531: Of thing that helpeth ofte noght;
11532: Bot what I hadde afore thoght
11533: To speke, whanne I come there,
11534: It is foryete, as noght ne were,
11536: That of nothing which I have noted
11537: I can noght thanne a note singe,
11538: Bot al is out of knowlechinge:
11539: Thus, what for joie and what for drede,
11541: So that, mi fader, of this Slowthe
11542: I have you said the pleine trowthe;
11543: Ye mai it as you list redresce:
11546: Sey now forth what you list to me,
11547: For I wol only do be you.
11548: Mi Sone, I have wel herd how thou
11549: Hast seid, and that thou most amende:
11550: For love his grace wol noght sende
11551: To that man which dar axe non.
11554: God wot, and yit that men beseche
11555: His will is; for withoute bedes
11556: He doth his grace in fewe stedes:
11557: And what man that foryet himselve,
11558: Among a thousand be noght tuelve,
11559: That wol him take in remembraunce,
11560: Bot lete him falle and take his chaunce.
11561: Forthi pull up a besi herte,
11562: Mi Sone, and let nothing asterte
11565: Which many a love hath set behinde,
11566: A tale of gret ensample I finde,
11567: Wherof it is pite to wite
11568: In the manere as it is write.
11569: King Demephon, whan he be Schipe
11574: To londe, and rested for a throwe.
11575: And fell that ilke time thus,
11577: Which qweene was of the contre,
11579: Withinne a Castell nyh the stronde,
11580: Wher Demephon cam up to londe.
11581: Phillis sche hihte, and of yong age
11582: And of stature and of visage
11583: Sche hadde al that hire best besemeth.
11584: Of Demephon riht wel hire qwemeth,
11585: Whan he was come, and made him chiere;
11586: And he, that was of his manere
11587: A lusti knyht, ne myhte asterte
11588: That he ne sette on hire his herte;
11589: So that withinne a day or tuo
11590: He thoghte, how evere that it go,
11592: And gan his herte to commune
11593: With goodly wordes in hire Ere;
11594: And forto put hire out of fere,
11595: He swor and hath his trowthe pliht
11596: To be for evere hire oghne knyht.
11597: And thus with hire he stille abod,
11598: Ther while his Schip on Anker rod,
11599: And hadde ynowh of time and space
11600: To speke of love and seche grace.
11601: This ladi herde al that he seide,
11602: And hou he swor and hou he preide,
11605: As thogh it were trowthe and feith,
11606: Sche lieveth al that evere he seith,
11608: Sche granteth him al that he wolde.
11609: Thus was he for the time in joie,
11610: Til that he scholde go to Troie;
11611: Bot tho sche made mochel sorwe,
11612: And he his trowthe leith to borwe
11613: To come, if that he live may,
11616: Bot were hem lieve or were hem lothe,
11617: To Schipe he goth and forth he wente
11618: To Troie, as was his ferste entente.
11619: The daies gon, the Monthe passeth,
11620: Hire love encresceth and his lasseth,
11621: For him sche lefte slep and mete,
11622: And he his time hath al foryete;
11623: So that this wofull yonge qweene,
11624: Which wot noght what it mihte meene,
11625: A lettre sende and preide him come,
11626: And seith how sche is overcome
11627: With strengthe of love in such a wise,
11628: That sche noght longe mai suffise
11629: To liven out of his presence;
11631: The trowthe which he hath behote,
11632: Wherof sche loveth him so hote,
11633: Sche seith, that if he lengere lette
11634: Of such a day as sche him sette,
11635: Sche scholde sterven in his Slowthe,
11636: Which were a schame unto his trowthe.
11637: This lettre is forth upon hire sonde,
11639: Sche tok, as she that wolde abide
11640: And waite upon that ilke tyde
11641: Which sche hath in hire lettre write.
11642: Bot now is pite forto wite,
11643: As he dede erst, so he foryat
11645: Bot sche, which mihte noght do so,

14285: Mi Sone, and riht in such manere

14340: Mi Sone, of that thin herte siketh
14341: With sorwe, miht thou noght amende,
14342: Til love his grace wol thee sende,
14343: For thou thin oghne cause empeirest
14344: What time as thou thiself despeirest.
14345: I not what other thing availeth,
14346: Of hope whan the herte faileth,
14347: For such a Sor is incurable,
14348: And ek the goddes ben vengable:
14349: And that a man mai riht wel frede,
14350: These olde bokes who so rede,
14351: Of thing which hath befalle er this:
14352: Now hier of what ensample it is.
14354: Of Mese was the king Theucer,
14355: Which hadde a kniht to Sone, Iphis:
14356: Of love and he so maistred is,
14357: That he hath set al his corage,
14358: As to reguard of his lignage,
14359: Upon a Maide of lou astat.
14360: Bot thogh he were a potestat
14361: Of worldes good, he was soubgit
14362: To love, and put in such a plit,
14365: He can noght; for the more he preide,
14366: The lasse love on him sche leide.
14367: He was with love unwys constreigned,
14368: And sche with resoun was restreigned:
14369: The lustes of his herte he suieth,
14370: And sche for drede schame eschuieth,
14371: And as sche scholde, tok good hiede
14372: To save and kepe hir wommanhiede.
14373: And thus the thing stod in debat
14374: Betwen his lust and hire astat:
14375: He yaf, he sende, he spak be mouthe,
14376: Bot yit for oght that evere he couthe
14377: Unto his sped he fond no weie,
14378: So that he caste his hope aweie,
14379: Withinne his herte and gan despeire
14380: Fro dai to dai, and so empeire,
14381: That he hath lost al his delit
14382: Of lust, of Slep, of Appetit,
14383: That he thurgh strengthe of love lasseth
14385: As he which of his lif ne rowhte,
14386: His deth upon himself he sowhte,
14387: So that be nyhte his weie he nam,
14388: Ther wiste non wher he becam;
14389: The nyht was derk, ther schon no Mone,
14390: Tofore the gates he cam sone,
14391: Wher that this yonge Maiden was,
14394: So stille that ther was noman
14395: It herde, and thanne he seide thus:
14398: Of love is every mannes chaunce,
14399: Ye knowen al min hole herte,
14400: That I ne mai your hond asterte;
14401: On you is evere that I crie,
14402: And yit you deigneth noght to plie,
14403: Ne toward me youre Ere encline.
14404: Thus for I se no medicine
14405: To make an ende of mi querele,

17041: So hath his lust no juggement,

17049: Mi Sone, hast thou such covoitise?
17050: Nai, fader, such love I despise,
17051: And whil I live schal don evere,

17062: Such on ther is I wolde have,

17064: Mi Sone, of that thou woldest so,
17065: I am noght wroth, bot over this
17066: I wol thee tellen hou it is.
17067: For ther be men, whiche otherwise,
17069: Of that thei sen a womman riche,
17070: Ther wol thei al here love affiche;
17071: Noght for the beaute of hire face,
17072: Ne yit for vertu ne for grace,
17073: Which sche hath elles riht ynowh,

17083: Mi Sone, tell riht as it is.
17086: For trewli, fader, I love oon
17087: So wel with al myn hertes thoght,
17088: That certes, thogh sche hadde noght,
17089: And were as povere as Medea,
17091: I wolde hir noght the lasse love;

17096: Yaf many a worthi riche thing,

17104: Were also riche as suche tuelve,
17105: I couthe noght, thogh it wer so,
17106: No betre love hir than I do.
17107: For I love in so plein a wise,
17109: As for poverte or for richesse
17110: Mi love is nouther mor ne lesse.
17111: For in good feith I trowe this,
17113: Forwhy and he mi ladi sihe,
17114: That he thurgh lokinge of his yhe

17119: Be so it were such a man,

17125: Ne schal noght take hem be the slieve;

17129: Wher that here gold is in the cofre,
17130: And wol non other love profre:
17131: Bot who so wot what love amounteth
17133: Than mai he knowe and taken hiede
17134: That al the lust of wommanhiede,
17135: Which mai ben in a ladi face,
17136: Mi ladi hath, and ek of grace
17137: If men schull yiven hire a pris,
17138: Thei mai wel seie hou sche is wys
17139: And sobre and simple of contenance,

17142: Sche hath pleinli: for thilke nyht

17144: Nature sette in hire at ones
17146: That I mai wel afferme and sein,
17151: And therto, as I have you told,
17152: Yit hath sche more a thousendfold
17153: Of bounte, and schortli to telle,
17154: Sche is the pure hed and welle
17155: And Mirour and ensample of goode.
17157: Me thenkth it oughte ynow suffise
17159: To love such on and to serve,
17160: Which with hire chiere can deserve
17162: Than sche per cas that richest is
17163: And hath of gold a Milion.
17166: I seie noght sche is haveles,
17167: That sche nys riche and wel at ese,
17168: And hath ynow wherwith to plese
17169: Of worldes good whom that hire liste;
17170: Bot o thing wolde I wel ye wiste,
17171: That nevere for no worldes good
17173: Bot only riht for pure love;
17174: That wot the hihe god above.
17175: Nou, fader, what seie ye therto?
17176: Mi Sone, I seie it is wel do.
17177: For tak of this riht good believe,
17178: What man that wole himself relieve
17179: To love in eny other wise,
17180: He schal wel finde his coveitise

17182: For such a love mai noght laste.
17183: Bot nou, men sein, in oure daies
17184: Men maken bot a fewe assaies,
17185: Bot if the cause be richesse;
17186: Forthi the love is wel the lesse.
17187: And who that wolde ensamples telle,
17188: Be olde daies as thei felle,
17189: Than mihte a man wel understonde
17190: Such love mai noght longe stonde.
17191: Now herkne, Sone, and thou schalt hiere
17192: A gret ensample of this matiere.
17193: To trete upon the cas of love,
17194: So as we tolden hiere above,

17196: Of Puile whilom was a king,
17199: After the nature of his age
17200: Was yit noght falle in his corage
17201: The lust of wommen forto knowe.
17202: So it betidde upon a throwe
17203: This lord fell into gret seknesse:
17206: To make him hol; and therupon
17207: A worthi maister which ther was
17208: Yaf him conseil upon this cas,
17209: That if he wolde have parfit hele,
17210: He scholde with a womman dele,
17211: A freissh, a yong, a lusti wiht,
17212: To don him compaignie a nyht:
17213: For thanne he seide him redily,
17214: That he schal be al hol therby,
17215: And otherwise he kneu no cure.
17216: This king, which stod in aventure
17217: Of lif and deth, for medicine
17219: His Steward, whom he tristeth wel,
17220: He tok, and tolde him everydel,
17221: Hou that this maister hadde seid:
17222: And therupon he hath him preid
17225: Of such on as be covenable
17227: And bad him, hou that evere it stod,
17228: That he schal spare for no good,
17229: For his will is riht wel to paie.
17230: The Steward seide he wolde assaie:
17231: Bot nou hierafter thou schalt wite,
17232: As I finde in the bokes write,
17236: A lusti ladi hath to wyve,
17237: Which natheles for gold he tok
17238: And noght for love, as seith the bok.

18551: And manye with a knyf sche scherth,
18552: And alle into hir char sche berth.
18553: Thus whan sche hath the hulles sought,
18554: The flodes ther foryat sche nought,
18557: To hem sche wente and ther sche nom
18558: Bothe of the water and the fom,
18559: The sond and ek the smale stones,
18560: Whiche as sche ches out for the nones,
18561: And of the rede See a part,
18562: That was behovelich to hire art,
18563: Sche tok, and after that aboute
18565: In feldes and in many greves,
18566: And ek a part sche tok of leves:
18567: Bot thing which mihte hire most availe
18568: Sche fond in Crete and in Thessaile.
18569: In daies and in nyhtes Nyne,
18570: With gret travaile and with gret pyne,
18571: Sche was pourveid of every piece,
18574: Hir char sche let awai to gon,
18575: And tok out ferst that was therinne;
18576: For tho sche thoghte to beginne
18579: As sche that was with Air enclosed
18580: And mihte of noman be desclosed.
18581: Sche tok up turves of the lond
18583: Al heled with the grene gras,
18584: Of which an Alter mad ther was
18586: Of art magique and the maistresse,
18587: And eft an other to Juvente,
18588: As sche which dede hir hole entente.
18589: Tho tok sche fieldwode and verveyne,
18590: Of herbes ben noght betre tueine,
18594: Sche made, and with that hastely
18595: A wether which was blak sche slouh,
18596: And out therof the blod sche drouh
18597: And dede into the pettes tuo;
18598: Warm melk sche putte also therto
18599: With hony meynd: and in such wise
18600: Sche gan to make hir sacrifice,
18601: And cride and preide forth withal
18604: And so sche soghte out al the line
18605: Of hem that longen to that craft,
18607: And preide hem alle, as sche wel couthe,
18608: To grante Eson his ferste youthe.
18609: This olde Eson broght forth was tho,
18610: Awei sche bad alle othre go
18612: And with that word thei wenten alle,
18613: And leften there hem tuo al one.
18614: And tho sche gan to gaspe and gone,
18617: So that with spellinge of hir charmes
18618: Sche tok Eson in bothe hire armes,
18619: And made him forto slepe faste,
18620: And him upon hire herbes caste.
18621: The blake wether tho sche tok,
18622: And hiewh the fleissh, as doth a cok;
18623: On either alter part sche leide,
18624: And with the charmes that sche seide
18625: A fyr doun fro the Sky alyhte
18626: And made it forto brenne lyhte.
18627: Bot whan Medea sawh it brenne,
18628: Anon sche gan to sterte and renne
18630: Ther was no beste which goth oute
18631: More wylde than sche semeth ther:
18632: Aboute hir schuldres hyng hir her,
18633: As thogh sche were oute of hir mynde
18634: And torned in an other kynde.
18635: Tho lay ther certein wode cleft,
18636: Of which the pieces nou and eft
18637: Sche made hem in the pettes wete,
18638: And put hem in the fyri hete,
18639: And tok the brond with al the blase,
18640: And thries sche began to rase
18641: Aboute Eson, ther as he slepte;
18642: And eft with water, which sche kepte,
18643: Sche made a cercle aboute him thries,
18644: And eft with fyr of sulphre twyes:
18645: Ful many an other thing sche dede,
18646: Which is noght writen in this stede.
18647: Bot tho sche ran so up and doun,
18648: Sche made many a wonder soun,
18652: Somtime spekth as don the men:
18653: And riht so as hir jargoun strangeth,
18654: In sondri wise hir forme changeth,
18655: Sche semeth faie and no womman;
18656: For with the craftes that sche can
18657: Sche was, as who seith, a goddesse,
18658: And what hir liste, more or lesse,
18659: Sche dede, in bokes as we finde,
18661: Bot who that wole of wondres hiere,
18662: What thing sche wroghte in this matiere,
18663: To make an ende of that sche gan,
18666: Whan it was time forto done,
18667: Sche sette a caldron on the fyr,
18668: In which was al the hole atir,
18670: Of jus, of water and of blod,
18671: And let it buile in such a plit,
18672: Til that sche sawh the spume whyt;
18673: And tho sche caste in rynde and rote,
18674: And sed and flour that was for bote,
18675: With many an herbe and many a ston,
18676: Wherof sche hath ther many on:
18678: To hire hath alle his scales lent,
18679: Chelidre hire yaf his addres skin,
18680: And sche to builen caste hem in;
18681: A part ek of the horned Oule,
18682: The which men hiere on nyhtes houle;
18683: And of a Raven, which was told
18685: Sche tok the hed with al the bile;
18686: And as the medicine it wile,
18688: Of the Seewolf, and for the hele
18689: Of Eson, with a thousand mo
18690: Of thinges that sche hadde tho,
18691: In that Caldroun togedre as blyve
18692: Sche putte, and tok thanne of Olyve
18693: A drie branche hem with to stere,
18694: The which anon gan floure and bere
18695: And waxe al freissh and grene ayein.
18696: Whan sche this vertu hadde sein,
18697: Sche let the leste drope of alle
18698: Upon the bare flor doun falle;
18699: Anon ther sprong up flour and gras,
18700: Where as the drope falle was,
18701: And wox anon al medwe grene,
18702: So that it mihte wel be sene.
18705: And goth to Eson ther he lay,
18706: And tok a swerd was of assay,
18707: With which a wounde upon his side
18708: Sche made, that therout mai slyde
18709: The blod withinne, which was old
18710: And sek and trouble and fieble and cold.
18711: And tho sche tok unto his us
18712: Of herbes al the beste jus,
18713: And poured it into his wounde;
18714: That made his veynes fulle and sounde:
18715: And tho sche made his wounde clos,
18716: And tok his hond, and up he ros;
18717: And tho sche yaf him drinke a drauhte,
18718: Of which his youthe ayein he cauhte,
18719: His hed, his herte and his visage
18722: And lich unto the freisshe Maii,
18723: Whan passed ben the colde shoures,
18724: Riht so recovereth he his floures.
18725: Lo, what mihte eny man devise,
18726: A womman schewe in eny wise
18727: Mor hertly love in every stede,
18729: Ferst sche made him the flees to winne,
18730: And after that fro kiththe and kinne
18731: With gret tresor with him sche stal,
18732: And to his fader forth withal
18733: His Elde hath torned into youthe,
18734: Which thing non other womman couthe:
18735: Bot hou it was to hire aquit,
18737: King Peleuµs his Em was ded,
18738: Jason bar corone on his hed,
18740: Bot whanne he scholde of riht fulfille
18741: The trouthe, which to hire afore
18742: He hadde in thyle of Colchos swore,
18744: For he an other hath received,
18745: Which dowhter was to king Creon,
18746: Creusa sche hihte, and thus Jason,
18747: As he that was to love untrewe,
18748: Medea lefte and tok a newe.
18749: Bot that was after sone aboght:
18750: Medea with hire art hath wroght
18751: Of cloth of gold a mantel riche,
18753: And that was unto Creusa sent
18754: In name of yifte and of present,
18756: And whan that yonge freisshe queene
18758: Anon therof the fyr sprong oute
18759: And brente hir bothe fleissh and bon.
18761: With bothe his Sones on hire hond,
18762: And seide, "O thou of every lond
18764: Lo, this schal be thi forfeture."
18765: With that sche bothe his Sones slouh
18766: Before his yhe, and he outdrouh
18767: His swerd and wold have slayn hir tho,
18770: Wher as sche pleigneth upon love,
18771: As sche that was with that goddesse,
18772: And he was left in gret destresse.
18773: Thus miht thou se what sorwe it doth
18774: To swere an oth which is noght soth,
18776: Mi Sone, be wel war forthi,
18777: And kep that thou be noght forswore:
18778: For this, which I have told tofore,
18780: Mi fader, I may lieve it wel,
18781: For I have herde it ofte seie
18782: Hou Jason tok the flees aweie
18783: Fro Colchos, bot yit herde I noght
18784: Be whom it was ferst thider broght.
18785: And for it were good to hiere,
18786: If that you liste at mi preiere
18787: To telle, I wolde you beseche.
18788: Mi Sone, who that wole it seche,
18789: In bokes he mai finde it write;
18790: And natheles, if thou wolt wite,
18791: In the manere as thou hast preid
18792: I schal the telle hou it is seid.
18793: The fame of thilke schepes fell,
18794: Which in Colchos, as it befell,
18795: Was al of gold, schal nevere deie;
18796: Wherof I thenke for to seie
18797: Hou it cam ferst into that yle.
18798: Ther was a king in thilke whyle
18800: The Cronique of his name was;
18801: And hadde a wif, which Philen hihte,
18802: Be whom, so as fortune it dihte,
18803: He hadde of children yonge tuo.
18804: Frixus the ferste was of tho,
18805: A knave child, riht fair withalle;
18806: A dowhter ek, the which men calle
18807: Hellen, he hadde be this wif.
18808: Bot for ther mai no mannes lif
18810: This worthi queene, as thou miht hiere,
18811: Er that the children were of age,
18812: Tok of hire ende the passage,
18813: With gret worschipe and was begrave.
18814: What thing it liketh god to have
18815: It is gret reson to ben his;
18816: Forthi this king, so as it is,
18819: Whan it was time forto wedde,
18820: A newe wif he tok to bedde,
18821: Which Yno hihte and was a Mayde,
18822: And ek the dowhter, as men saide,
18823: Of Cadme, which a king also
18824: Was holde in thilke daies tho.
18825: Whan Yno was the kinges make,
18826: Sche caste hou that sche mihte make
18827: These children to here fader lothe,
18828: And schope a wyle ayein hem bothe,
18829: Which to the king was al unknowe.
18830: A yeer or tuo sche let do sowe
18831: The lond with sode whete aboute,
18832: Wherof no corn mai springen oute;
18833: And thus be sleyhte and be covine
18834: Aros the derthe and the famine
18835: Thurghout the lond in such a wise,
18836: So that the king a sacrifise
18837: Upon the point of this destresse
18838: To Ceres, which is the goddesse
18839: Of corn, hath schape him forto yive,
18840: To loke if it mai be foryive,
18841: The meschief which was in his lond.
18842: Bot sche, which knew tofor the hond
18843: The circumstance of al this thing,
18844: Ayein the cominge of the king
18845: Into the temple, hath schape so,
18846: Of hire acord that alle tho
18847: Whiche of the temple prestes were
18848: Have seid and full declared there
18849: Unto the king, bot if so be
18851: Of Frixus and of Hellen bothe,
18852: With whom the goddes ben so wrothe,
18853: That whil tho children ben therinne,
18855: Wherof to gete him eny corn.
18856: Thus was it seid, thus was it sworn
18857: Of all the Prestes that ther are;
18858: And sche which causeth al this fare
18859: Seid ek therto what that sche wolde,
18860: And every man thanne after tolde
18861: So as the queene hem hadde preid.
18862: The king, which hath his Ere leid,
18863: And lieveth al that evere he herde,
18865: And seith that levere him is to chese
18867: Than him and al the remenant
18869: Unto the lond which he schal kepe:
18870: And bad his wif to take kepe
18871: In what manere is best to done,
18873: Out of this world. And sche anon
18875: Bot ferst sche made hem forto swere
18876: That thei the children scholden bere
18877: Unto the See, that non it knowe,
18879: The children to the See ben lad,
18880: Wher in the wise as Yno bad
18881: These men be redy forto do.
18883: Is hote, appiereth in the stede,
18884: And hath unto the men forbede
18885: That thei the children noght ne sle;
18886: Bot bad hem loke into the See
18887: And taken hiede of that thei sihen.
18888: Ther swam a Schep tofore here yhen,
18889: Whos flees of burned gold was al;
18892: Thei scholde anon these children sette
18894: And al was do, riht as sche spak,
18895: Wherof the men gon hom ayein.
18896: And fell so, as the bokes sein,
18898: Which of the See was wo bego,
18899: For pure drede hire herte hath lore,
18900: That fro the Schep, which hath hire bore,
18901: As sche that was swounende feint,
18902: Sche fell, and hath hirselve dreint;
18903: With Frixus and this Schep forth swam,
18904: Til he to thyle of Colchos cam,
18905: Where Juno the goddesse he fond,
18906: Which tok the Schep unto the lond,
18907: And sette it there in such a wise
18908: As thou tofore hast herd devise,
18909: Wherof cam after al the wo,
18911: Unto Medee, as it is spoke.
18912: Mi fader, who that hath tobroke
18913: His trouthe, as ye have told above,
18914: He is noght worthi forto love
18915: Ne be beloved, as me semeth:
18919: If that you list to taken hiede
18921: In loves cause ayein the vice
18923: What ther is more I wolde wite.
18924: Mi Sone, this I finde write,
18925: Ther is yit on of thilke brood,
18926: Which only for the worldes good,
18927: To make a Tresor of Moneie,
18932: Which makth on riche, an other bare.
18933: Upon the bench sittende on hih
18935: Full clothed of his oghne suite,
18936: Which after gold makth chace and suite
18937: With his brocours, that renne aboute
18938: Lich unto racches in a route.
18939: Such lucre is non above grounde,
18940: Which is noght of tho racches founde;
18941: For wher thei se beyete sterte,
18942: That schal hem in no wise asterte,
18943: Bot thei it dryve into the net
18944: Of lucre, which Usure hath set.
18946: To al that evere he beith and selleth
18947: He hath ordeined of his sleyhte
18949: Outward he selleth be the lasse,
18950: And with the more he makth his tasse,
18951: Wherof his hous is full withinne.
18952: He reccheth noght, be so he winne,
18953: Though that ther lese ten or tuelve:
18954: His love is al toward himselve
18955: And to non other, bot he se
18956: That he mai winne suche thre;
18957: For wher he schal oght yive or lene,
18958: He wol ayeinward take a bene,
18959: Ther he hath lent the smale pese.
18960: And riht so ther ben manye of these
18961: Lovers, that thogh thei love a lyte,
18962: That scarsly wolde it weie a myte,
18963: Yit wolde thei have a pound again,
18964: As doth Usure in his bargain.
18966: It falleth more unto the riche,
18967: Als wel of love as of beyete,
18968: Than unto hem that be noght grete,
18969: And, as who seith, ben simple and povere;
18970: For sielden is whan thei recovere,
18971: Bot if it be thurgh gret decerte.
18975: And take of love his avantage,
18976: Forth with the help of his brocage,
18977: That maken seme wher is noght.
18978: And thus fulofte is love boght
18979: For litel what, and mochel take,
18980: With false weyhtes that thei make.
18981: Nou, Sone, of that I seide above
18982: Thou wost what Usure is of love:
18983: Tell me forthi what so thou wilt,
18984: If thou therof hast eny gilt.
18985: Mi fader, nay, for ought I hiere.
18986: For of tho pointz ye tolden hiere
18987: I wol you be mi trouthe assure,
18988: Mi weyhte of love and mi mesure
18989: Hath be mor large and mor certein
18990: Than evere I tok of love ayein:
18991: For so yit couthe I nevere of sleyhte,
18992: To take ayein be double weyhte
18993: Of love mor than I have yive.
18994: For als so wiss mot I be schrive
18996: As so yit couthe I nevere winne,
18997: Ne yit so mochel, soth to sein,
18998: That evere I mihte have half ayein
18999: Of so full love as I have lent:
19000: And if myn happ were so wel went,
19001: That for the hole I mihte have half,
19002: Me thenkth I were a goddeshalf.
19003: For where Usure wole have double,
19004: Mi conscience is noght so trouble,
19005: I biede nevere as to my del
19006: Bot of the hole an halvendel;
19007: That is non excess, as me thenketh.
19009: For wel I wot that wol noght be,
19010: For every day the betre I se
19011: That hou so evere I yive or lene
19012: Mi love in place ther I mene,
19013: For oght that evere I axe or crave,
19015: Bot yit for that I wol noght lete,
19016: What so befalle of mi beyete,
19017: That I ne schal hire yive and lene
19018: Mi love and al mi thoght so clene,
19019: That toward me schal noght beleve.
19020: And if sche of hire goode leve
19022: I wot the laste of my bargain
19023: Schal stonde upon so gret a lost,
19024: That I mai neveremor the cost
19025: Recovere in this world til I die.
19026: So that touchende of this partie
19027: I mai me wel excuse and schal;
19029: If eny brocour for me wente,
19030: That point cam nevere in myn entente:
19031: So that the more me merveilleth,
19032: What thing it is mi ladi eilleth,
19033: That al myn herte and al my time
19034: Sche hath, and doth no betre bime.
19035: I have herd seid that thoght is fre,
19037: To you, mi fader, that ben hiere
19039: I dar min herte wel desclose.
19041: Which as ye telle in love is used,
19042: Mi ladi mai noght ben excused;
19043: That for o lokinge of hire yeµ
19044: Min hole herte til I dye
19045: With al that evere I may and can
19046: Sche hath me wonne to hire man:
19047: Wherof, me thenkth, good reson wolde
19049: And yive a part, ther sche hath al.
19050: I not what falle hierafter schal,
19051: Bot into nou yit dar I sein,
19053: A goodli word in such a wise,
19056: I not hou sche hire conscience
19058: Be large weyhte and gret mesure
19059: Sche hath mi love, and I have noght
19060: Of that which I have diere boght,
19061: And with myn herte I have it paid;
19062: Bot al that is asyde laid,
19064: Hire oghte stonde if ful gret doute,
19065: Til sche redresce such a sinne,
19066: That sche wole al mi love winne
19067: And yifth me noght to live by:
19068: Noght als so moche as "grant mercy"
19069: Hir list to seie, of which I mihte
19070: Som of mi grete peine allyhte.
19071: Bot of this point, lo, thus I fare
19072: As he that paith for his chaffare,
19073: And beith it diere, and yit hath non,
19074: So mot he nedes povere gon:
19075: Thus beie I diere and have no love,
19076: That I ne mai noght come above
19077: To winne of love non encress.
19080: And if mi ladi be to wyte,
19081: I preie to god such grace hir sende
19082: That sche be time it mot amende.
19083: Mi Sone, of that thou hast ansuerd
19084: Touchende Usure I have al herd,
19085: Hou thou of love hast wonne smale:
19086: Bot that thou tellest in thi tale
19088: Me thenkth tho wordes thou misusest.
19090: Thou seist hou sche for o lokinge
19091: Thin hole herte fro the tok:
19092: Sche mai be such, that hire o lok
19094: So hast thou wel thin herte sold,
19095: Whan thou hast that is more worth.
19096: And ek of that thou tellest forth,
19097: Hou that hire weyhte of love unevene
19098: Is unto thin, under the hevene
19099: Stod nevere in evene that balance
19101: Such is the statut of his lawe,
19102: That thogh thi love more drawe
19103: And peise in the balance more,
19104: Thou miht noght axe ayein therfore
19105: Of duete, bot al of grace.
19106: For love is lord in every place,
19107: Ther mai no lawe him justefie
19109: That he ne wole after his wille
19110: Whom that him liketh spede or spille.
19111: To love a man mai wel beginne,
19112: Bot whether he schal lese or winne,
19113: That wot noman til ate laste:
19115: Mi Sone, bot abyd thin ende,
19116: Per cas al mai to goode wende.
19117: Bot that thou hast me told and said,
19118: Of o thing I am riht wel paid,
19119: That thou be sleyhte ne be guile
19122: Is sore venged, as I rede.
19124: No wonder is thogh thei receiven
19125: After the wrong that thei decerven;
19126: For whom as evere that thei serven
19127: And do plesance for a whyle,
19128: Yit ate laste here oghne guile
19130: Which god of his vengance sendeth,
19131: As be ensample of time go
19132: A man mai finde it hath be so.
19133: It fell somtime, as it was sene,
19134: The hihe goddesse and the queene
19137: For sche was evere in on acord
19138: With Jupiter, that was hire lord,
19139: To gete him othre loves newe,
19140: Thurgh such brocage and was untrewe
19142: Bot sche, which of no schame dredeth,
19143: With queinte wordes and with slyhe
19144: Blente in such wise hir lady yhe,
19145: As sche to whom that Juno triste,
19146: So that therof sche nothing wiste.
19147: Bot so prive mai be nothing,
19148: That it ne comth to knowleching;
19149: Thing don upon the derke nyht
19150: Is after knowe on daies liht:
19151: So it befell, that ate laste
19152: Al that this slyhe maiden caste
19154: For as the sothe mot be knowe,
19157: With fals brocage hath take usure
19158: Of love mor than his mesure,
19159: Whan he tok othre than his wif,
19161: Which hadde ben of his assent.
19162: And thus was al the game schent;
19163: She soffreth him, as sche mot nede,
19164: Bot the brocour of his misdede,
19165: Sche which hir conseil yaf therto,
19166: On hire is the vengance do:
19167: For Juno with hire wordes hote,
19168: This Maiden, which Eccho was hote,
19169: Reproveth and seith in this wise:
19171: Hast thou thin oghne ladi served]
19172: Thou hast gret peine wel deserved,
19173: That thou canst maken it so queinte,
19175: Towardes me, that am thi queene,
19176: Wherof thou madest me to wene
19179: Al be it so him nedeth noght.
19180: Bot upon thee it schal be boght,
19181: Which art prive to tho doinges,
19182: And me fulofte of thi lesinges
19183: Deceived hast: nou is the day
19184: That I thi while aquite may;
19185: And for thou hast to me conceled
19186: That my lord hath with othre deled,
19187: I schal thee sette in such a kende,
19188: That evere unto the worldes ende
19189: Al that thou hierest thou schalt telle,
19190: And clappe it out as doth a belle."
19191: And with that word sche was forschape,
19192: Ther may no vois hire mouth ascape,
19193: What man that in the wodes crieth,
19195: And what word that him list to sein,
19196: The same word sche seith ayein.
19197: Thus sche, which whilom hadde leve
19198: To duelle in chambre, mot beleve
19199: In wodes and on helles bothe,
19200: For such brocage as wyves lothe,
19201: Which doth here lordes hertes change

22600: Riht as me thoghte that I syhe

22620: Me thenkth as thogh I were aslepe

22624: Out of my thought, and hiede take
22625: Hou that the sothe stant in dede,

22631: To take of love a newe thorst,
22633: For thanne comth the blanche fievere,

22635: And so it coldeth at myn herte,

22637: In such a point that I ne deie:

22646: Lo, thus I tempre mi diete,

22648: That al mi wit is herteles,
22649: And al myn herte, ther it sit,
22650: Is, as who seith, withoute wit;

22654: Betwen a drunke man and me.

22658: The more I may; so that me thinketh,
22659: My thurst schal nevere ben aqueint.

22662: For wel I fiele in mi degre

27977: This finde I write of essamplaire:
27979: Be whom that Rome stod governed,

27981: Of that he was to familier,

27992: Fulofte it comth the worse aboute;

28253: Men clepe, and was a werreiour,

28331: As thou til othre men hast do,

32281: Lo thus, mi Sone, myht thou liere
32282: What is to love in good manere,

32284: The mede arist of the servise;

32325: Bot, fader, for ye ben a clerk

32382: To him which thenkth to ben a king;

32410: Of now and ek of time gon,

32450: Bot al the whiles that I hove

32489: The wofull peine of loves maladie,

32491: Min herte hath so bewhaped with sotie,

32493: I finde it evere redy to assaile
32494: Mi resoun, which that can him noght defende:
32495: Thus seche I help, wherof I mihte amende.
32496: Ferst to Nature if that I me compleigne,
32497: Ther finde I hou that every creature
32498: Som time ayer hath love in his demeine,
32499: So that the litel wrenne in his mesure
32500: Hath yit of kinde a love under his cure;
32501: And I bot on desire, of which I misse:
32502: And thus, bot I, hath every kinde his blisse.
32503: The resoun of my wit it overpasseth,
32504: Of that Nature techeth me the weie
32505: To love, and yit no certein sche compasseth
32506: Hou I schal spede, and thus betwen the tweie
32507: I stonde, and not if I schal live or deie.

32509: I mai noght fle, that I ne love algate.
32510: Upon miself is thilke tale come,
32511: Hou whilom Pan, which is the god of kinde,
32512: With love wrastlede and was overcome:
32513: For evere I wrastle and evere I am behinde,
32514: That I no strengthe in al min herte finde,
32515: Wherof that I mai stonden eny throwe;

32517: Whom nedeth help, he mot his helpe crave,

32527: Lith couched, that fortune is overrunne,

33415: That y nomore of love make,
33416: Which many an herte hath overtake,
33418: Fro reson in to lawe of kynde;
33419: Wher as the wisdom goth aweie
33420: And can nought se the ryhte weie
33421: How to governe his oghne estat,
33423: Withinne him self, and can nought leve.
33424: And thus forthy my final leve
33425: I take now for evere more,
33427: Of love and of his dedly hele,
33429: For his nature is so divers,
33430: That it hath evere som travers
33431: Or of to moche or of to lite,
33433: Bot if him faile or that or this.
33434: Bot thilke love which that is
33437: Such love is goodly forto have,
33438: Such love mai the bodi save,
33439: Such love mai the soule amende,
33440: The hyhe god such love ous sende
33442: So that above in thilke place
33443: Wher resteth love and alle pes,
